examples.en: You can return any unsold stock, so would you let us sell our products here?
examples.ja: 残品はこちらで引き取るので、こちらのお店で販売させてもらえませんか。

examples.en: Before we leave the store tonight, let’s go ahead and count the remaining stock.
examples.ja: 今夜店を出発する前に残品を数えておきましょう。

examples.en: We sold the remaining goods at half price.
examples.ja: 残品は半額で処分しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>remainder</kanji> <kanji>product</kanji>s are the things that haven't been sold. They're the <vocabulary>unsold merchandise</vocabulary>. They're the <vocabulary>remaining stock</vocabulary>.

This is a very specific word that is mainly used in the context of inventory management or retail sales.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that ひん changes to ぴん.

examples.en: Viet is good at separating his public and private selves.
examples.ja: ビエトは本音と建前を使い分けるのが上手い。

examples.en: They're just pretending that's the case for appearance's sake.
examples.ja: それは建前上、そういうことにしてるだけですよ。

examples.en: It is often said that "the contrast between one’s personal feelings and public behavior" is a uniquely Japanese culture, but it is found in every country in the world.
examples.ja: よく「本音と建前」は日本独特の文化だと言われますが、世界中どこの国にもあるものですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
We all <kanji>build</kanji> up something in <kanji>front</kanji> of ourselves. It's the front we present to the world, the <vocabulary>public behavior</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>public stance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>social niceties</vocabulary> that maintain harmony.

建前 is very important in Japan. For example, you might find yourself invited to an acquaintance's home out of courtesy, with the expectation that you’ll decline (also out of courtesy!). A host of a party may say "just bring yourself," but guests know this could be 建前, and considering their own 建前, they bring a small gift anyways.  People can also be reluctant to say "no" to things, like drinks with coworkers when they really want to go home, and may not to show it when they find situations inconvenient or unpleasant. So you might need some guesswork to peek behind the 建前 that people build up in front of themselves!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like 建物 in that it's read as たて, which is like the word 建てる even though the て isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like 建てる but the て gets pushed into the kanji.

examples.en: The team that won a glorious victory this time is Team Tofugu!
examples.ja: 今回、勝利の栄光を手にしたのは、トーフグチームです！

examples.en: That quality of that comedian's material makes it hard to believe they won the M-1 Grand Prix.
examples.ja: あの芸人のネタ、『M1グランプリ』の栄光を勝ち取ったとは思えないクオリティだな。

examples.en: Viet said, "There's no one more pathetic than a yakuza who talks about past glory."
examples.ja: 「昔の栄光を語るヤクザほどミジメな者はない」ってビエトが言ってたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>prosper</kanji>ed so much that <kanji>light</kanji> seems to shine forth from your every pore in a golden aura. With the wealth, fame, and admiration you have achieved, you are the walking embodiment of <vocabulary>glory</vocabulary>.

栄光 is commonly used in expressions like 過去の栄光 (past glory), referring to the great achievements or status that one had in the past.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm worried about whether they'll obey the agreement.
examples.ja: ちゃんと取り決めを守ってもらえるのか、不安です。

examples.en: You should make living arrangements with your roommate.
examples.ja: ルームメイトと生活上の取り決めをしておいた方がいいよ。

examples.en: According to the contract between our company and Ms. Salmon, it is unfortunate, but we did not make an agreement regarding her appearance in our competitor’s commercials.
examples.ja: サーモンさんと我が社で取り交わした契約によると、残念なことに彼女が競合他社のCMに出演することについて我々は何の取り決めも行っておりませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: You've <kanji>take</kanji>n a <kanji>decision</kanji> from someone. By doing this, you've created a kind of <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary> with them. Imagine yourself pulling this decision out of the person. They don't want to necessarily give it to you, but they're letting you pull it out of them, kind of. When you've pulled it out, you've come to an arrangement, though they've pulled some of your decision out too.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for both kanji, which you might have guessed already since there's hiragana sticking out of both of them. The 取り comes from 取る and the 決め comes from 決める. Put them together and what have you got? Bibbidi bobbidi とりきめ!

examples.en: It promotes the breakdown of alcohol.
examples.ja: アルコールの分解を進めてくれます。

examples.en: When I was little, I would play with watches by disassembling them.
examples.ja: 小さいころ、よく時計を分解してあそんでいました。

examples.en: Dad, can you improve the decomposition efficiency of electrolysis?
examples.ja: お父さん、電気分解の分解効率を向上させることはできる？

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>divide</kanji> and <kanji>untie</kanji> things, you're unraveling the connections between them. In other words, you're doing a <vocabulary>breakdown</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dismantling</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That book has influenced the lives of many people.
examples.ja: その本は、多くの人の人生に影響を与えました。

examples.en: I granted permission to the part-time student worker to access the company database.
examples.ja: アルバイトの学生に会社のデータベースにアクセスする権限を与えた。

examples.en: People will dislike you if you keep making remarks that cause harm to others.
examples.ja: 人にダメージを与えるような発言ばかりしていると、嫌われますよ。

examples.en: Today let's practice responding to small talk in a way that gives a good impression to the other person.
examples.ja: 今日は、相手にいい印象を与えるようなスモールトークの受け答えの練習をしましょう。

examples.en: First and foremost, I would like to express my sincere thanks for taking time out of your busy schedules to be here and for granting me the fantastic opportunity to give this presentation.
examples.ja: まず初めに、お忙しい中足をお運び頂き誠に有り難うございます。また、このような素晴らしいプレゼンテーションの機会を与えて頂いたことにも、感謝申し上げます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to grant</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word that is generally used in writing. In conversations, people commonly use more relaxed words like あげる or くれる.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You go <vocabulary>to give</vocabulary> a bone to your dog. <reading>Atta</reading> (あた) boy, Sparky! <reading>Atta</reading> boy.

examples.en: Many towns in Germany value their cityscapes.
examples.ja: ドイツには、景観を大切にしている町が多い。

examples.en: Oh, that's going to ruin the scenery, isn't it?
examples.ja: あーあ、あれじゃあ、せっかくの景観が台無しだね。

examples.en: I really like Kyoto’s scenery.
examples.ja: 私は京都の景観がとても好きです。

examples.en: In Kyoto, an ordinance has been established to protect the cityscape.
examples.ja: 京都では、景観を守るための条例が定められています。

examples.en: The local government of this city has a solid landscape plan.
examples.ja: この市の自治体は景観計画をきちんと立てています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Quite the <kanji>scene</kanji>, this <kanji>view</kanji> is. So what you're looking at is a <vocabulary>landscape</vocabulary>. This often refers to a <vocabulary>cityscape</vocabulary> or the general <vocabulary>scenery</vocabulary> of an area.

This is a formal word that’s commonly used in the context of urban planning or environmental design.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am not a type of person who belongs to a group.
examples.ja: グループに属するのは私のガラじゃないんです。

examples.en: Whose group were you in when you were in grade four?
examples.ja: 四年生の時は誰のグループに属していたの？

examples.en: Tulips are flowers that fall under the Liliaceae family.
examples.ja: チューリップはユリ科に属する花です。

examples.en: The starting month of the service will be the month in which the service start date belongs to. The service start date will be the day on which we confirm that the customer has received the SIM card.
examples.ja: サービス開始月は、サービス開始日が属する月となります。サービス開始日は、お客様がSIMカードの受け取られたことを弊社が確認した日となります。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>belong</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary>.

属する is a formal term for describing someone or something’s belonging to or being part of a group, category or classification.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. This kanji is going <vocabulary>to belong to</vocabulary> you.

examples.en: Apparently, this café is popular with the older crowd.
examples.ja: このカフェは年輩の方に人気だそうです。

examples.en: Next to me, an elderly woman was drinking coffee by herself.
examples.ja: となりの席では、ご年輩の女性が一人でコーヒーを飲んでいらっしゃいました。

examples.en: The other driver in the accident was a 70 year old elderly person.
examples.ja: 事故の相手の運転手は70才くらいの年輩者でした。

meaning_mnemonic:
For <kanji>year</kanji>s and years, your <kanji>comrade</kanji>s have been with you, but now they're all <vocabulary>elderly</vocabulary>.

This is a less common version of 年配, but you'll still sometimes encounter it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As this vocab is identical to 年配, it's also read the same. Just remember that the はい turns into ぱい!

examples.en: My cousin’s wedding will take place the month after next.
examples.ja: 再来月にいとこの式があるんです。

examples.en: My son who went to fight in the war will finally come back the month after next.
examples.ja: 戦争に行った息子がようやく再来月帰ってくるんです。

examples.en: I can take a week-long vacation the month after next, so wanna go somewhere together?
examples.ja: 再来月に一週間の休暇が取れるんだけど、どこか一緒にいかない？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>next month</kanji> (来月) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it <kanji>again</kanji>. That month is the <vocabulary>month after next</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: By the year after next, the economy should have improved.
examples.ja: 再来年には景気もよくなっているでしょう。

examples.en: I plan to return to my family's home in Japan the year after next.
examples.ja: 再来年に日本の実家に帰るつもりです。

examples.en: Shouldn't we propose a two-year contract that lasts until the year after next?
examples.ja: 再来年まで継続する二年契約を提案するべきではないでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>next year</kanji> (来年), but then you do a year <kanji>again</kanji>. That's the <vocabulary>year after next</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I finally got my hands on this ice cream, which is sold exclusively in the Kansai region.
examples.ja: 関西限定販売のアイスクリーム、やっと手に入れたんだ。

examples.en: Wait, is this only on sale during the Halloween season? I'm a sucker for the phrase “limited-time offer.”
examples.ja: え、これってハロウィンの季節だけの限定販売なの！？私、「限定販売」っていう言葉に弱いんだよね。

examples.en: I'm considering buying a life-sized model of a limited express train with sleeper cars, but it seems that in Japan, only three units will be sold as a limited edition.
examples.ja: 寝台車付き特急の実物大型模型を買おうか迷っているんだけど、日本では三台のみの限定販売になるみたいなんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
When a 限定 (limit) is applied to 販売 (selling), it’s a sort of <vocabulary>exclusive sale</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>limited offer</vocabulary>.

限定販売 is a sales strategy where companies limit the availability of their products to certain regions, stores, time frames, or club members.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am such a coward, so I can't talk back even if I wanted to.
examples.ja: 私は腰抜けだから言い返したくても言い返せないの。

examples.en: The next time you call me a coward, I will not forgive you!
examples.ja: 次にオレを腰抜けと呼んだら、許さないぞ！

examples.en: It doesn't bother me one bit what those cowards say.
examples.ja: 腰抜け共に何を言われても痛くもかゆくもないよ。

examples.en: There are too many coward employees who resign before being promoted to management.
examples.ja: 管理職に昇進する前に辞職する腰抜け社員が多すぎる。

meaning_mnemonic: You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If your <kanji>waist</kanji> falls out, you can't remain standing. You have to curl up on the ground, like a <vocabulary>coward</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you've learned already. Go you!

examples.en: Necessary particles are missing from this sentence.
examples.ja: この文では必要な助詞が抜けていますよ。

examples.en: It was in the fall of 2020 that Viet said he wanted to leave the Yakuza group.
examples.ja: ビエトがヤクザグループから抜けたいと言ったのは２０２０年の秋のことだった。

examples.en: I'm busy right now. I'm watching a video of a balloon being deflated.
examples.ja: 今、忙しい。風船の空気が抜けるところのビデオを見てるの。

examples.en: The Tooth Fairy won't come to you in Japan if your teeth fall out.
examples.ja: 日本では歯が抜けてもトゥースフェアリーは来ないよ。

examples.en: As we passed through the forest, a bright blue ocean was spread out before us.
examples.ja: 森を抜けると、そこには真っ青な海が広がっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 抜く means "to pull something out"? 抜ける describes something coming out of where it was, so it means <vocabulary>to come out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fall out</vocabulary>. 

This can be used for air coming out of a balloon, hair falling out, or pages missing from a book. It also means passing through places or leaving a group you were a part of.

To distinguish this word from 抜く, imagine a bunch of <reading>kale</reading> (ける) coming out of the ground on its own! Nobody pulled it out, it just came out by itself.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also, it is the same as 抜く.

examples.en: Apparently, Mr. Tanaka intends to catch the culprits using these plastic bottles.
examples.ja: 田中さんは、このペットボトルを使って犯人を捕えるつもりだそうです。

examples.en: ”Pokemon" is a game in which players catch various Pokemon by using Pokeballs, etc., and make the captured Pokemon fight, grow, and become stronger.
examples.ja: 『ポケモン』は、モンスターボールなどで色んなポケモンを捕え、その捕えたポケモンを戦わせて育てて強くしていくゲームです。

examples.en: An idol's job may be to capture the hearts and minds of fans, but my job is to catch idols on dates with my camera.
examples.ja: アイドルの仕事はファンの心を捕えることかもしれませんが、私の仕事は、アイドルのデート現場をカメラで捕えることです。

examples.en: Catching mice is my cat’s specialty.
examples.ja: 私の猫は鼠を捕えることが得意なんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>catch</kanji>, and 捕える means <vocabulary>to capture something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to catch something</vocabulary>. 

捕える is often used in writing to describe having someone captured to keep them from escaping. But it can also be used in more abstract contexts, like capturing a moment in a photograph, grasping a concept or idea, or seizing an opportunity.

You can remember the meaning for this because everyone wants to capture <reading>el</reading>ves (える). Sorry, elves… You're just so cool, people want to capture and keep you forever.
reading_mnemonic: You recently learned 捕まる, which uses the same kanji, but this word has a totally different reading. To remember it, just think about how the meaning of 捕える kind of resembles the verb 捉える that you learned a while ago. 捕える is mostly for capturing things, and 捉える is mostly for grasping ideas. So it kinda makes sense that they'd have the same とらえる reading, right?

examples.en: I'd like to hang the clock here, but I'm not sure if it will hang right.
examples.ja: 時計をココに掛けたいんだけど、うまく掛かるかな。

examples.en: A man's silk hat was hung on a pole hanger.
examples.ja: ポールハンガーには、男性のシルクハットが掛かっていた。

examples.en: When I went to the Louvre, the Mona Lisa was hanging crooked.
examples.ja: ルーヴル美術館に行った時、モナリザが曲がって掛かっていた。

examples.en: Oh, fish got hooked!
examples.ja: お、魚が掛かったぞ！

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 掛ける is "to hang something"? Well, 掛かる focuses on the fact that something is hanging, without specifying who did it. So it means <vocabulary>to be hung</vocabulary>. Use it to say a picture is hung on the wall, for example. 

掛かる can also mean <vocabulary>to be hooked</vocabulary>, whether it's the picture hooked to the wall or a fish that happens <vocabulary>to be caught</vocabulary> on a hook. 

These uses are all intransitive, so you don't need a direct object them. A hint for this is that 掛かる ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 掛ける, so as long as you know that you know this too.

examples.en: This seems to be a good place to hide for hide and seek!
examples.ja: ここ、隠れんぼで隠れるのにいいかも！

examples.en: Oh, the moon has hidden away.
examples.ja: あー、お月様が隠れちゃった。

examples.en: Under his shirt, there is a hidden tattoo of KFC chicken.
examples.ja: アイツのシャツの下には、KFCのチキンのタトゥーが隠れている。

examples.en: "Oh no. I think I just saw my ex. Quick, hide!" "What? You mean Fugu?" "No. Shark." "Shark? Who’s Shark? You have way too many exes!"
examples.ja: 「やばい。多分あれ元彼だ。速く隠れなきゃ。」「まじで？フグってこと？」「違うよ。サメだよ。」「 サメ？サメって誰のこと？てか、あんた元カレ多すぎだっつーの！」

meaning_mnemonic:
隠す is "to hide something." 隠れる is <vocabulary>to hide oneself</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>to hide</vocabulary>. You know this because when someone is hiding, it's <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for anyone else to find them. They take this hide-and-seek thing pretty seriously, you know!

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to be hidden</vocabulary> because sometimes the subject is an inanimate object, as in 月が雲に隠れる (the moon is hidden in the cloud).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 隠す. So as long as you know that you know this as well.

examples.en: There was no price written on this item.
examples.ja: この商品には値段が書かれていませんでした。

examples.en: Buying without even looking at the price, you are indeed the president of the company.
examples.ja: 値段を見もせずに買うなんて、さすが社長ですね。

examples.en: It’s true that we are working on our TV tie-in book, but the price hasn’t been decided yet.
examples.ja: テレビとタイアップした書籍を手がけているのは本当だが、まだ値段は決まっていない。

examples.en: Of course, we cannot put a price on human life. But there are times when it is necessary to calculate the price of someone's life. Do you know when that is?
examples.ja: もちろん、人の命に値段はつけられません。でも、誰かの命の値段を算出する必要がある時もあります。皆さんは、それがどんな時か分かりますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>value</kanji> is in various <kanji>steps</kanji>. Each step is a different amount, and each amount is a <vocabulary>price</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cost</vocabulary>.

値段 refers to the price attached to something you can buy, like in stores or markets. For example, you could use 値段 to ask how much something costs at a shop or when talking about the price of a particular meal.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading for 値 plus the on'yomi reading for 段. Combine them together to get the reading here. You've learned both of these readings already, so just remember 値 is ね because you <reading>neigh</reading> (ね) when you see a good <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Nothing is better than good health.
examples.ja: 健康に勝るものは何もないですよ。

examples.en: I started swimming for my health.
examples.ja: 健康のために水泳を始めました。

examples.en: This virus rarely affects healthy people.
examples.ja: このウィルスは、健康な人にはほとんど心配いりません。

examples.en: Is company-paid health insurance included in the fringe benefits?
examples.ja: 会社側が負担する健康保険は、諸手当の中に含まれているのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: You're so <kanji>healthy</kanji> it puts you at <kanji>ease</kanji>. That's your <vocabulary>health</vocabulary>! So healthful, go you!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Is amnesia an incurable disease?
examples.ja: 健忘症は不治の病なんでしょうか。

examples.en: Last year, Mr. Arita suffered from transient amnesia.
examples.ja: 去年、有田さんは一過性の健忘症になってしまった。

examples.en: The doctor told me that he suspected amnesia.
examples.ja: お医者さんに健忘症の疑いがあると言われました。

examples.en: I have a relative who is suffering from amnesia.
examples.ja: 健忘症に苦しんでいる親戚がいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>healthy</kanji> bit of <kanji>forget</kanji>ting <kanji>symptom</kanji>s means you might have <vocabulary>amnesia</vocabulary>.

健忘症 often refers to short-term <vocabulary>memory loss</vocabulary>, either full or partial, but some people might also use it in a sort of joking way for everyday <vocabulary>forgetfulness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Well, your team is efficient but not effective, don’t you think?
examples.ja: でも、あなたのチームは効率的だけど効果的ではないよね。

examples.en: Where are the pressure points that are effective at shaking off drowsiness?
examples.ja: 眠気を覚ますのに効果的なツボはどこですか。

examples.en: It is said that walking is most effective in the morning.
examples.ja: ウォーキングが最も効果的なのは、朝だと言われています。

examples.en: To effectively lose weight, it is important to get a good night's sleep.
examples.ja: 効果的にやせるには、睡眠時間をしっかり確保することが大切です。

examples.en: Performance based salaries are the most effective and fairest ways to attract good workers.
examples.ja: 成果主義の給与制度は、良い社員を引き込む最も効果的で公平な方法である。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 効果 means "effect"? Add <kanji>~like</kanji> to that and it's <vocabulary>effective</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Congratulations on finding a job!
examples.ja: 就職おめでとう！

examples.en: We're going to celebrate my friend's new job tomorrow night.
examples.ja: 明日の夜、友達の就職祝いをします。

examples.en: I am worried about whether I will be able to find a job after graduation.
examples.ja: 卒業後、ちゃんと就職できるか不安なんです。

examples.en: "I’ve had several job interviews, but I haven’t received any job offers yet.” “Join the club.”
examples.ja: 「いくつか就職の面接をしたんだけど、まだどこからも内定が出ないんだ。」「お互い大変だな。」

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Getting a position</kanji> of <kanji>employment</kanji> means <vocabulary>finding employment</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>getting a job</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What are Mr. Hayashi's working hours?
examples.ja: 林さんの就業時間を教えてください。

examples.en: We meet on a monthly basis to discuss employment regulations.
examples.ja: 就業規則についての話し合いをするために、 私たちは月一のペースで会っている。

examples.en: When I go to Hello Work (employment service center), they only recommend part-time jobs to me.
examples.ja: ハローワークに行っても、就業形態がパートのみの仕事しかすすめてもらえないんだよ。

examples.en: The working population refers to the number of individuals within the labor force who are employed and earning income. The working population can be further categorized into two groups: those who are actively working, and those who are on leave and not working due to various reasons.
examples.ja: 就業人口とは、労働力人口の中で、職業に就いて収入を得ている人の数のことです。 就業人口は、就業中の就業者と、何らかの事情により就業していない休業者に分けられます。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>get a position</kanji> in some <kanji>business</kanji>, you’re considered <vocabulary>working</vocabulary>.

就業 is a formal word that can refer to both <vocabulary>being employed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>being at work</vocabulary> for the day. It’s commonly used in kanji compounds, such as 就業時間 (working hours) and 就業規則 (employment regulations).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I couldn't even go out because of the injury, it was such a boring week.
examples.ja: ケガのせいで外出もできなかったので、かなり退屈な一週間でした。

examples.en: I was bored, so it was good timing.
examples.ja: 退屈していたのでちょうどよかったです。

examples.en: Lately, my work has become monotonous and I'm very bored.
examples.ja: 最近、仕事が単調になっちゃって、すごく退屈なんだよ。

examples.en: Beneath the endless sky, students had to listen to the principal’s endless and boring speech.
examples.ja: 果てしなく続く空の下で、生徒たちは果てしなく長くて退屈な校長の話を聞かなくてはならなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>retreat</kanji>! I <kanji>yield</kanji>! I can't take it anymore, it's so <vocabulary>boring</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself giving up on whatever you're doing because you're so darn bored. You can't stand it. You have to retreat. You are ready to yield. Booooooring.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I heard that Koichi will host a rolled sushi party this Friday.
examples.ja: 今度の金曜日にコウイチが巻きずしパーティーをするんだって。

examples.en: Why is it that American makizushi has the seaweed rolled on the inside?
examples.ja: どうしてアメリカの巻きずしはのりが内側に巻かれているんですか。

examples.en: There are Japanese people who have never made makizushi too.
examples.ja: 日本人でも巻きずしを作ったことがない人はいるよ。

examples.en: "You should try the sushi roll. I'm sure you'll like it." "Okay, if you say so."
examples.ja: 「君も巻きずしを食べてみるべきだよ。きっと気に入ると思うよ。」「わかったわ。あなたがそう言うのなら。」

meaning_mnemonic:
巻く is "to roll." ずし is すし. This is <vocabulary>rolled sushi</vocabulary>.

Makizushi refers to cylindrical rolled sushi, which is commonly served in bite-sized pieces. If it's shaped like a cone, it's known as 手巻きずし (temakizushi).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 巻く.

examples.en: No matter how many times I make them, my spring rolls always get stolen.
examples.ja: 作っても作っても春巻きをぬすまれるんです。

examples.en: "Did you eat my spring rolls?" "Sorry, I did."
examples.ja: 「私の春巻き食べたでしょ？」「ごめん。その通りだよ。」

examples.en: My favorite food is fresh spring rolls.
examples.ja: 私の大好物は生春巻きです。

meaning_mnemonic: 巻く is "to roll up." If you roll up spring, you get a roll that's spring flavored. These are known as <vocabulary>spring rolls</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 春 and 巻く.

examples.en: Do your best Japan! Hang in there Japan!
examples.ja: 頑張れニッポン、負けるなニッポン！

examples.en: You'll be fine, Haru-chan. I'm sure you'll pass the test. Good luck!
examples.ja: 大丈夫だって。春ちゃんならきっと受かるよ。頑張れ。

examples.en: Hang in there, help is almost here!
examples.ja: 頑張れ、あとちょっとで助けが来るぞ！

examples.en: Well, don’t worry about the results, just try your best!
examples.ja: まあ、結果を気にせずに、頑張れよ！

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 頑張る means “to persevere” or “to do one’s best”? This time you're telling someone to 頑張る, so this word means something like <vocabulary>do your best</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>hang in there</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>good luck</vocabulary>! Speaking of which, 頑張れ, you!
reading_mnemonic:
The reading comes from 頑張る. Just watch out for that rendaku on 張る! You've seen it before, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

Remember how when it's time to 頑張る (to persevere), you always scream "baa"? Not sure why, but it's a great motivator for you. So you do the same when you cheer for others. When you tell them <vocabulary>Do your best</vocabulary>, you also scream <reading>baa</reading> (ば) at them. When you tell them <vocabulary>Hang in there</vocabulary>, you scream "baa!" If it makes you persevere, it must work the same for others, right? Baa!

examples.en: Mr. Yamazaki has a habit of inflating his nostrils when he gets angry.
examples.ja: 山崎さんは怒ると鼻の穴を大きくふくらませるクセがあるんです。

examples.en: It's weird. I don't think I had said anything that would make him mad.
examples.ja: おかしいな？別に怒らせるようなこと言ったつもりはないんだけど...。

examples.en: I'm sorry. Please don't get so angry.
examples.ja: ごめんってば。そんなに怒らないでよ。

examples.en: "Fugu, you don’t understand why Salmon is mad at you, do you?" "No, I have no idea." "That’s what I thought."
examples.ja: 「フグ、どうしてサーモンがお前のことを怒っているのか分からないんだろ？」「うん。さっぱり分からないよ。」「そうだと思ったよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>angry</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get angry</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're starting <vocabulary>to get angry</vocabulary> about something. It's mostly this <reading>ok</reading>ra (おこ). It tastes terrible.

examples.en: I really don't like people who yell at others.
examples.ja: 私、怒鳴る人、ホントに嫌なんだよね。

examples.en: My boss yells at me so much that I got a hole in my stomach.
examples.ja: 上司に怒鳴られてばっかりで、胃に穴が空いちゃったよ。

examples.en: Mr. Fujisaki has very mild personality, so I have never seen him shout at somebody.
examples.ja: 藤崎さんは温厚な性格で、怒鳴っているところを見たことがありません。

examples.en: "Kinnikuma yells a lot." "Yeah, but don’t worry. His bark is worse than his bite."
examples.ja: 「キンニクマってよく怒鳴るよね。」「そうだね。でも、心配しないで。彼は口は悪いけど根は悪い人ではないから。」

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>angry</kanji> <kanji>chirp</kanji> is a type of shout. The verb version is <vocabulary>to yell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>.

怒鳴る suggests anger, as you can tell from the kanji, so it's used when someone yells or shouts to scold others or to express anger or frustration.
reading_mnemonic: This one is a bit tricky, as it uses the on'yomi reading you learned for 怒 and the kun'yomi reading for 鳴る, so try to keep that in mind!

examples.en: You seem like you don't have any worries at all, huh? That must be nice.
examples.ja: あんたは何の悩みもなさそうでいいよね。

examples.en: I've been bothered by how easily my stockings get runs.
examples.ja: ストッキングがすぐに伝線しちゃうのが悩みなんです。

examples.en: In the past, my concern was not being able to confide in others, but now I can talk about anything.
examples.ja: 昔は悩みを人に打ち明けることができないのが悩みでしたが、今では何でも言えるようになりました。

examples.en: I don't mind hearing about your troubles, but I'm running out of money. If you want to eat out with me, it's your treat.
examples.ja: 悩み事の相談に乗るのは構わないんだけど、金欠なんだよね。外食したいなら、あんたの奢りだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of <kanji>worry</kanji>, making it <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>a trouble</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Nicely done, no need to have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> about it.

examples.en: Many women wonder whether to continue working after giving birth.
examples.ja: 出産後も仕事を続けるかを悩む女性は多い。

examples.en: I am troubled by harassment from my neighbors.
examples.ja: 近所の人からの嫌がらせに悩んでいます。

examples.en: You are still young, what do you need to be so worried about?
examples.ja: まだ若いのに、何をそんなに悩む必要があるんだよ！

examples.en: "Hey! What’s troubling you?" "My girlfriend dumped me last night."
examples.ja: 「どうしたの？何を悩んでいるの？」「昨日、彼女に振られたんだ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>worry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.

悩む is often intransitive, like 彼はいつも悩んでいる (he's always worrying). But it can also be transitive, in which case it'll take a direct object, like 彼女のことを悩む (to worry about her).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary> about it.

examples.en: There is an annoying person, and it’s troubling me.
examples.ja: 迷惑な人がいて、困ってるんです。

examples.en: If it's not too much trouble, is it okay to leave it to you?
examples.ja: ご迷惑じゃなければ、お願いしてもいいですか？

examples.en: Lately, I have been getting a lot of junk mail.
examples.ja: 最近、迷惑メールがたくさん送られて来るようになった。

examples.en: I am bad at Japanese, so I might be an inconvenience to you.
examples.ja: 日本語が下手なので、あなたに迷惑をかけてしまうかもしれません。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've been led <kanji>astray</kanji> and you've been <kanji>misguided</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>trouble</vocabulary>, and indeed a <vocabulary>troublesome</vocabulary> <vocabulary>inconvenience</vocabulary> all this is.

迷惑 refers to a <vocabulary>nuisance</vocabulary> that bothers others, like trimming your toenails or speaking loudly on the phone in public.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I succumbed to a sweet temptation and ended up eating cake.
examples.ja: あま〜い誘惑に負けて、ケーキを食べてしまった。

examples.en: What? My boyfriend wouldn't do something as flirtatious as hitting on someone else! You probably seduced him, didn't you?
examples.ja: はあ？私の彼氏がナンパなんてチャラいことするはずないじゃない。どうせあんたが誘惑したんでしょ？

examples.en: What do you think is the best way to prevent your child from being tempted and led astray by bad influences?
examples.ja: 自分の子供が、悪いヤツらに誘惑されて悪いことに手を出すのを防ぐには、どうすればいいと思いますか？

examples.en: Fugu could not resist the temptation to kiss Salmon.
examples.ja: フグは、サーモンの唇を奪いたいという誘惑に抗うことはできなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You're being <kanji>invited</kanji>, but you're also being <kanji>misguided</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>seduction</vocabulary> that's talking. A misguided invitation is never a good thing!

This word also translates to <vocabulary>temptation</vocabulary>, but keep in mind that 誘惑’s focus is more on an external factor that entices someone into succumbing to temptation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Mr Suto is good at seeing people's true nature.
examples.ja: 首藤さんは人の素質を見抜くのがうまいんですよ。

examples.en: My mother is great at seeing through my father’s lies.
examples.ja: うちの母親は父親のウソを見抜くのがうまい。

examples.en: I knew that oil supplies have been dwindling in recent years, but I wasn't able to find out why.
examples.ja: 近ごろ石油の供給が少なくなってきているのは知っていましたが、その理由は見抜けませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 抜く means "to pull something out." Whenever you <kanji>see</kanji> something and pull something out of it, you're able <vocabulary>to see something's true nature</vocabulary>. You're able <vocabulary>to see through</vocabulary> things like situations, lies, and people.

見抜く often suggests figuring something out instinctively, with sharp insight or keen perception, especially when it comes to understanding the essence or true nature of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is the reading for 見る and 抜く put together.

examples.en: I'm too dumb to have noticed. Thanks for telling me.
examples.ja: オレ、間抜けだから、気づかなかったよ。言ってくれてありがとう。

examples.en: You idiot!
examples.ja: この間抜け野郎！

examples.en: I feel ashamed of the stupid reply I sent.
examples.ja: 間抜けな返事をしてしまい、はずかしく思っています。

examples.en: Did you see his dumb face?
examples.ja: アイツの間抜けヅラ、見た？

examples.en: I don’t want him to think of me as a stupid country bumpkin.
examples.ja: 彼に間抜けな田舎者のお上りさんだと思われたくないの。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 抜ける is "to fall out." If an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> falls out of you, you're totally spaced out. You won't learn anything and you'll become an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary>.

間抜け can refer to both a person who does something foolish and to the foolish actions themselves. It's often used to criticize <vocabulary>dumb</vocabulary> behavior.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the ま reading of 間 and from 抜く.

examples.en: Is there a function in Excel to extract only the month part of a date?
examples.ja: エクセルで日付の月の部分だけを抜き出す関数ってありますか？

examples.en: Q4: What is the reason why Tomoko started crying? Answer the question by selecting seventeen characters from the text.
examples.ja: 問4： 友子が泣き出した理由は何ですか。文中の言葉を17字で抜き出して答えなさい。

examples.en: What do you do with your old computer or smartphone? If you take them to a recycling shop, there is a risk that a malicious third party could extract the data, right?
examples.ja: いらなくなったパソコンとかスマホってどうしてる？リサイクルショップとかに持っていったら、悪意ある第三者にデータを抜き出される危険性があるよね？

examples.en: He secretly started to pull a gun out of his business suit.
examples.ja: 彼は背広から銃をそっと抜き出した。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 抜く means "to pull something out" and 出す means "to remove," so this word also means <vocabulary>to pull something out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to extract</vocabulary>.

More specifically, 抜き出す means to pull something out from a larger set of something. For example, this could mean taking a single bill out of your wallet, or selecting specific data from a large dataset.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are from 抜く and 出す, combined together. Know those two and you'll be able to read this word as well.

examples.en: Charlie said he's inviting me to the chocolate factory next time!
examples.ja: チャーリーが、今度チョコレート工場に招待するよって言ってくれたんだ！

examples.en: I was invited to the Tofugu Christmas party, but I caught the flu and couldn't go.
examples.ja: トーフグのクリスマス会に招待されたが、インフルエンザにかかって行けなかった。

examples.en: How many people are you planning to invite to the wedding party?
examples.ja: ウェディングパーティーには何人ぐらい招待するつもりなの？

examples.en: Have you decided which friends to invite over for your birthday party?
examples.ja: どのお友達を誕生日会に招待するか決めましたか。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>beckon</kanji> someone to come to you, but then you <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is because they aren't really near you, so your beckon is more like an invitation. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary> .

招待する is a formal word for inviting someone, particularly to formal events or places.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Still can't find any clues?
examples.ja: 手掛かりはまだ見つからないのですか。

examples.en: We are currently searching wholeheartedly for clues that will lead us to a solution.
examples.ja: 今は全力で、問題解決の糸口となるような手掛かりを探しています。

examples.en: Have the police found any clues regarding the mystery of the vanishing bacon?
examples.ja: 警察は消えたベーコンの謎について何か手掛かりを見つけましたか？

examples.en: Mr. Fujikawa's statement provided a clue to the culprit's trickery.
examples.ja: 藤川さんの発言が、犯人のトリックを見抜く手掛かりになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 掛かる can mean "to be hooked." If you're doing something physical like climbing and your <kanji>hand</kanji> hooks onto something, that thing is called a <vocabulary>handhold</vocabulary>.

Figuratively, this can also mean <vocabulary>clue</vocabulary>, since a clue is something you grasp onto, much like a handhold, to help you progress in solving a crime or mystery. This figurative use of 手掛かり is actually the most common!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 手 plus 掛かる put together. Just watch out for that rendaku.

examples.en: "Guess what? I got a promotion at work!" "Really? That’s awesome! Congrats!"
examples.ja: 「聞いて聞いて、昇進したんだ！」「本当？すごいね！おめでとう！」

examples.en: What? Isn't the pace of your promotions really fast?
examples.ja: え、お前の昇進のペース、めっちゃ早くない？

examples.en: I missed out on my long-awaited chance of promotion.
examples.ja: 折角の昇進のチャンスを逃してしまった。

examples.en: Mr. Tasaki quit his job one month after he got promoted. What happened to him?
examples.ja: 田崎さんは昇進してから一か月で会社を辞めてしまいました。何があったんでしょう？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Ascend</kanji> and <kanji>advance</kanji>! Congratulations, you ascend and advance by getting a new <vocabulary>job promotion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I draw manga in my spare time.
examples.ja: 暇な時にマンガをかいています。

examples.en: I admire Mr. Mimura's constant study of stocks in his spare time.
examples.ja: 三村さんは暇さえあれば常に株の勉強をしていて感心します。

examples.en: Lately, work has been so slow, you know? It's so idle that I feel like I'm going to die.
examples.ja: 最近仕事が暇でさー、暇すぎて死にそうなんだよね。

examples.en: We sell home electronic appliances like air purifiers, but not many customers come in and honestly, I have a lot of free time at the store.
examples.ja: 私達は空気洗浄機とか家電を販売してるんですが、お客さんがあまりこないので、お店では正直暇してます。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

暇 means the <vocabulary>spare time</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>free time</vocabulary> you have when you're <vocabulary>not busy</vocabulary> with work, school, or other obligations. It can also indicate a slow period for a business or a time when you have nothing to do, often suggesting a sense of boredom.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

In your <vocabulary>spare time</vocabulary> you like to drink <reading>hima</reading> (ひま), an off brand version of Zima.

examples.en: How far in advance do you usually make vacation plans?
examples.ja: いつもどのくらい前から休暇の予定を立てますか？

examples.en: I'm thinking of taking a slightly longer vacation this year.
examples.ja: 今年はちょっと長めに休暇を取ろうと思ってるんです。

examples.en: The day before the Christmas holidays ended, I got the flu.
examples.ja: クリスマス休暇が終わる前日にインフルエンザになってしまった。

examples.en: I wonder where I should go for my summer vacation this year.
examples.ja: 今年の夏季休暇はどこに行こうかな。

examples.en: Oh no! It's only August and I've already used up all my paid vacation days.
examples.ja: やばい！まだ八月なのに、有給休暇、もう全部使い切っちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>spare time</kanji> is your <vocabulary>vacation</vocabulary>. It is your <vocabulary>holiday</vocabulary>.

休暇 is a relatively formal word that commonly refers to <vocabulary>time off</vocabulary> from work, ranging from a day off to seasonal vacation to temporary leave.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to play UFO catcher, but I can't find a change machine.
examples.ja: UFOキャッチャーしたいのに、両替機が見つからない。

examples.en: Could you exchange this 10,000 yen bill for 1,000 yen bills?
examples.ja: この一万円札を千円札に両替してもらえませんか？

examples.en: Sorry, I’m afraid we don’t break bills.
examples.ja: すみません、両替はお断りしているんです。

examples.en: I’ll review today’s lesson about how to exchange money in Japanese later.
examples.ja: 後で、今日習った日本語での両替の仕方について復習したいと思います。

examples.en: I wanted to exchange money at Kansai Airport, but the exchange counter was closed.
examples.ja: 関西空港で両替しようと思ったんですが、両替所がしまっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Coins? Bills? <kanji>Both</kanji> can be <kanji>replace</kanji>d if you want to <vocabulary>change money</vocabulary> at this <vocabulary>money exchange</vocabulary>. Just don’t do your <vocabulary>currency exchange</vocabulary> at the airport — the rates aren’t so great.

You'll probably see this word the most in arcades where you can go to the 両替 machine and get coins to feed your crane game addiction.
reading_mnemonic: The reading here is a bit weird. Instead of just being か (it changes to が for the rendaku), it is がえ. Just think that if you want change exchanged, I'm your <reading>guy</reading> (がえ).

examples.en: I will replace this trash can bag with a new one!
examples.ja: このゴミ箱のゴミぶくろ、新しいのに取り替えるね！

examples.en: Hey, hey, can you swap my broccoli for that sausage?
examples.ja: ねえねえ、そのソーセージと私のブロッコリー、取り替えてくれない？

examples.en: Today, I learned from my father how to replace the toilet bowl.
examples.ja: 今日、お父さんから便器の取り替え方を教えてもらいました。

examples.en: We should gradually replace all of the office automation equipment for the latest versions.
examples.ja: そろそろ我々のOA機器を最新のものに取り替える方がいいんじゃないでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Take</kanji> and <kanji>replace</kanji> something. That is <vocabulary>to replace</vocabulary> something with something else.

取り替える generally means <vocabulary>to swap out</vocabulary> something with a new or different item of the same kind, like replacing an old gas meter with a new one, or exchanging books with your friend after you've both read your own.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 取る and 替える put together into one. If you know those words you'll be able to read and understand this one as well.

examples.en: My mother apologized for forgetting to bring me a change of clothes.
examples.ja: 母は、私の着替えを持ってくるのを忘れた事を謝りました。

examples.en: It's time to change into your pajamas!
examples.ja: パジャマにお着替えする時間だよー！

examples.en: My son is going through the "terrible twos" right now, so even just changing his clothes is a big pain.
examples.ja: 今うちの息子イヤイヤ期だからお着替えするだけでも一苦労だよ。

examples.en: Of course I brought a change of clothes for the kids, but I didn't expect to need a change of clothes for myself, so I had to buy some at Wal-Mart.
examples.ja: もちろん子供の着替えは持ってきていたけど、まさか自分の着替えが必要になるとは思ってもいなかったから、ウォルマートで買う羽目になったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 替える is "to replace"? Well, you're replacing what you <kanji>wear</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>change of clothes</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>spare clothes</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 着る and 替える put together. The か goes to が.

examples.en: I'm gonna master making the ultimate ramen before I die.
examples.ja: 死ぬまでに、究極のラーメンを極めるつもりです。

examples.en: Which kanji do you think is the ultimate in difficulty?
examples.ja: 皆さんは、究極に難しい漢字ってどれだと思いますか？

examples.en: Tomoko spent a half day on beating the ultimate-level monster.
examples.ja: 知子は究極レベルのモンスターを倒すのに半日を費やした。

examples.en: Even Mr. Sakaki congratulated me on finding out the ultimate fundamental truth of the universe.
examples.ja: あの榊氏までもが、私が宇宙の究極の原理を解明したことに祝いの言葉を述べてくれました。

meaning_mnemonic: You are trying to <kanji>research</kanji> the <kanji>extreme</kanji>s. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the <vocabulary>ultimate</vocabulary> weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My parents have decided to go to Antarctica this summer.
examples.ja: 私の両親は、この夏に南極に行ってみることを決心しました。

examples.en: I want to try making shaved ice with Antarctic ice.
examples.ja: 南極の氷でかき氷を作ってみたいんです。

examples.en: I watched the movie, The Chef of South Polar, and made up my mind to become a chef.
examples.ja: 南極料理人の映画を観て、料理人になる決意を固めました。

examples.en: The 1959 Antarctic Treaty established the rule that Antarctica is not the territory of any country.
examples.ja: 1959年の南極条約で、南極はどこの国の領土でもないというルールができました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>south</kanji>ern <kanji>extreme</kanji> is the <vocabulary>South Pole</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Antarctic</vocabulary>. It's about as south as you can go.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: "Would you like french fries as well?" "No thanks."
examples.ja: 「ごいっしょにポテトもいかがですか？」「いいえ、結構です。」

examples.en: “Would you like to play Pokemon Mr. Tanaka?" "Oh, I'm fine.”
examples.ja: 「田中さんもポケモンしませんか？」「あ、私は結構です。」

examples.en: "We'll give away mason jars that hold Koichi's farts to users who complete WaniKani level 30," "Really and truly, no thanks!"
examples.ja: 「ワニカニのレベル３０が終わったユーザーに、コウイチのオナラが入ったメイソンジャーをプレゼントします。」「本当に本当に結構です！」

examples.en: No, that’s okay. I don’t want dinner. Sorry, but I’m so stressed that I have no appetite.
examples.ja: いいえ、結構です。夕食はいりません。申し訳ありませんが、ストレスで食欲がないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: 結構 is something like "fine" or "alright." This is just a little more polite. You can use this to say <vocabulary>no thank you</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>I'm fine</vocabulary> to someone trying to offer you something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 結構.

examples.en: I'll get going soon so please don't mind me.
examples.ja: すぐ帰りますので、お構いなく。

examples.en: Please don't worry about us. We will take care of it ourselves.
examples.ja: うちの家のことは、どうかお構いなく。自分たちでなんとかしますから。

examples.en: The discussion proceeded without any regard to whether the president gave his approval or not.
examples.ja: 社長がOKと言おうが言うまいが、お構いなく話は進んだ。

examples.en: ”Would you like some coffee?" “No, thank you. Don’t worry about me.”
examples.ja: 「コーヒーはいかがですか？」「いえ、結構です。お構いなく。」

examples.en: I'm just looking, so don't mind me.
examples.ja: 見てるだけなので、お構いなく。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 構う is "to care about"? You can convert it into お構いなく to politely tell someone not to care about you. So this means, <vocabulary>don't mind me</vocabulary>.

It can also mean <vocabulary>without regard for</vocabulary>, especially when someone keeps doing something without caring about other people, their surroundings, or unfavorable conditions.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 構う, so if you know that you know this!

examples.en: What would you do if there was a massive earthquake in your town?
examples.ja: 皆さんは、もし皆さんが住む町で大規模な地震が起きたらどうしますか？

examples.en: I am currently learning about large language models (LLM) online.
examples.ja: 今はオンラインで大規模言語モデルについて学んでいます。

examples.en: I'm not really a fan of large parties, you know.
examples.ja: 私、大規模なパーティーって苦手なんだよね。

examples.en: The upcoming project is expected to be quite large in scale.
examples.ja: 今度のプロジェクトは、かなり大規模なものになる予定だよ。

examples.en: Hosokawa thanked Kojima for helping him stage a large-scale rally against resuming nuclear power plant operations.
examples.ja: 細川は、原発再稼働に反対する大規模デモの実現に協力してくれたことについて、児島に礼を述べた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 規模 is <kanji>scale</kanji>? Well, this is a big scale, which is on a <vocabulary>large scale</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our company's project teams are small in scale to enhance their agility.
examples.ja: うちの会社のプロジェクトチームは小回りが効くように、小規模化されているんです。

examples.en: Small businesses often require fewer initial costs because they operate on a small scale.
examples.ja: スモールビジネスは小規模で事業を行うので、少ない初期費用で始められることが多いです。

examples.en: This is a small-scale language model (SLM), so it consumes minimal power and can be run on low-capacity CPUs or GPUs.
examples.ja: これは小規模な言語モデル(SLM)なので消費電力が小さく、演算能力の小さなCPUやGPUでも実行できるんです。

examples.en: We all warned Keisuke against starting a small scale farm.
examples.ja: 私達はみんな、啓介に小規模農場なんて始めない方がいいと警告したんです。

meaning_mnemonic: 規模 is "scale." This is a <kanji>small</kanji> one, making this <vocabulary>small scale</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I tripped over a stairway and my knee bled.
examples.ja: 階段で転んでひざから血が出てしまった。

examples.en: When you go up the stairs, please take the train on the right.
examples.ja: 階段を上がったら、向かって右側の電車に乗って下さい。

examples.en: This is how we all climb the stairs to adulthood, one step at a time.
examples.ja: こうしてみんな、一歩ずつ大人の階段を上がっていくんだよ。

examples.en: Mitsuru thanked me for helping him clean the stairs.
examples.ja: 充は、私が階段の掃除を手伝った事に礼を述べた。

meaning_mnemonic: To get to another <kanji>floor</kanji> you have to go up one <kanji>step</kanji>, then another, and another… These are <vocabulary>stairs</vocabulary>. The word you're looking for is stairs! Do you have any 階段 in your house?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’m glad to hear that my Japanese is gradually getting better.
examples.ja: 私の日本語が段々うまくなっていると言ってもらえて、すごく嬉しいです。

examples.en: Mr. Yamada, be careful, the ground is stepped there!
examples.ja: 山田さん、そこ段々になってるから気をつけて！

examples.en: At first, I didn't like this painting of the terraced fields, but as I kept looking at it, I gradually started to like it.
examples.ja: この段々畑の絵、最初は好きじゃなかったけど、見てるうちに段々気に入ってきたんだよね。

examples.en: Gradually, things started to not look good.
examples.ja: 段々雲行きが怪しくなってきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Step</kanji> by <kanji>step</kanji>. If you take things step by step, you're moving up <vocabulary>gradually</vocabulary>, taking <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary>.

段々 is often used to describe gradual progress. But sometimes you'll see it used for terraced fields or buildings too, since they sorta resemble steps!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It is still too early to draw conclusions at this stage.
examples.ja: この段階で結論を出すのはまだ早すぎる。

examples.en: I think housing prices have reached the phase just before a sharp decline.
examples.ja: 住宅価格は、急落する直前の段階まで来ていると思うんです。

examples.en: Now, the project has entered the final phase with just a little bit left until the launch.
examples.ja: 今、プロジェクトはローンチまであと少しの最終段階に入っています。

examples.en: My boyfriend accused me of not telling him I was pregnant until I was in the advanced stages of pregnancy.
examples.ja: 彼氏は、私が妊娠からかなり経った段階まで妊娠の事実を伝えなかったことについて私を責めました。

meaning_mnemonic: Each time you take a <kanji>step</kanji> up, you reach a new <kanji>floor</kanji>… a new <vocabulary>stage</vocabulary>! We're talking metaphorical stages. You're making all kinds of progress. The first stage, the second stage. The third <vocabulary>phase</vocabulary>. Man, you're blowing through all the stages and phases of Japanese learning. Keep it up!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Now, please read the first section, Mr. Mori.
examples.ja: では、第一段は森さんが読んでください。

examples.en: In any TV program, it seems that popular idols, popular comedians, and popular actors always sit in the front row, after all.
examples.ja: やっぱりどのテレビ番組でも、第一段目の席には、人気アイドル、人気芸人、人気俳優が座るんだね。

examples.en: I may need to review the basics for the first step.
examples.ja: 第一段階として、まずは基本の復習をしなくちゃいけないかもしれない。

meaning_mnemonic: 第一 means "the first," and 段 is a <kanji>step</kanji>. So, this is <vocabulary>the first step</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, I might have seasoned it a bit strong. Sorry!
examples.ja: あ、味付け、ちょっと濃いかも。ごめんね！

examples.en: Isn't that makeup too heavy?
examples.ja: そのメイク、濃くない？

examples.en: I need a special-ordered razor in order to shave this thick hair.
examples.ja: この濃い毛をそるのに特注のカミソリが必要なんです。

examples.en: I’m thinking of dyeing his hair a deep purple.
examples.ja: 私は彼の髪は濃い紫色にしようかなって思ってるんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>dense</kanji>, and this can also mean <vocabulary>dense</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> in some contexts, like if you’re describing fog, or body hair! More generally, it can be used for anything that’s highly concentrated, so you can use it for things like <vocabulary>deep</vocabulary> colors, or <vocabulary>strong</vocabulary> coffee too!
reading_mnemonic: What’s the most <vocabulary>dense</vocabulary> thing you can think of? A <reading>子</reading> (こ). Children are so full of joy, you can practically see how dense, <vocabulary>thick</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>concentrated</vocabulary> the joy is.

examples.en: What is this mammographic density?
examples.ja: この、マンモグラフィ濃度って何ですか？

examples.en: This is a saline solution with a concentration of 20%.
examples.ja: これは濃度20%の食塩水です。

examples.en: Store-bought Thai curry paste contains high concentrations of salt, so I don't like it.
examples.ja: 市販のタイカレーペーストは、高濃度の塩分を含んでいるのであまり好きじゃありません。

examples.en: I’ll get back to you on your blood-alcohol concentration.
examples.ja: あなたの血中アルコール濃度については追って連絡致します。

meaning_mnemonic: When something is <kanji>dense</kanji> to a certain <kanji>degree</kanji>, you’re talking about the <vocabulary>density</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concentration</vocabulary> of something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: In Ms. Kishida's essay, she writes about her daily life with her mother in a wheelchair and her brother with Down syndrome.
examples.ja: 岸田さんのエッセーには、車いすのお母さんとダウン症の弟さんとの日々がつづられています。

examples.en: You must not get heatstroke, so please make sure to frequently stay hydrated!
examples.ja: 熱中症になるといけないので、こまめに水分をとってくださいね！

examples.en: Aren’t those early symptoms of dementia?
examples.ja: それって、認知症の初期症状じゃないですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Multiple <kanji>symptom</kanji>s combine to make a <vocabulary>syndrome</vocabulary>. If you see this at the end of a word, you know it means "______ syndrome," or else indicates some kind of health condition.  

〜症 is used in medical terms for certain health conditions, symptoms, or syndromes, like 熱中症 (heatstroke) or 認知症 (dementia).
reading_mnemonic: Since this is attached to things, it's treated like a jukugo word, so the on'yomi reading is used here.

examples.en: Do you have any other symptoms?
examples.ja: 他にも症状はありますか？

examples.en: It’s little by little, but the symptoms are improving.
examples.ja: 少しずつですが、症状の改善が見られます。

examples.en: What symptoms are you experiencing now?
examples.ja: 今はどのような症状が出ていますか？

examples.en: I consulted with my colleague once about my symptoms.
examples.ja: 私の症状について、一度同僚に相談しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>symptom</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji> is your <vocabulary>symptom</vocabulary>s that you have.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm suffering from insomnia and stomach cramps.
examples.ja: 不眠症と胃けいれんに悩まされています。

examples.en: Please sell me medicine that is effective for insomnia.
examples.ja: 不眠症に効く薬を売ってください。

examples.en: Working with him is so stressful that I got insomnia.
examples.ja: 彼と仕事をするのがストレスで、不眠症になってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji> shows you have a disorder that involves not sleeping. That is <vocabulary>insomnia</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Where does it hurt? Your head?
examples.ja: どこが痛いの？頭？

examples.en: No, I have a sore throat.
examples.ja: ううん、なんかノドが痛いの。

examples.en: Masako-chan gave me a good argument and it was painful to my ears.
examples.ja: 正子ちゃんに正論を言われて、耳が痛くなった。

examples.en: Our company should designate an outdoor smoking area because the smoke gets in my eyes in this room and it hurts.
examples.ja: この部屋じゃ煙が目に入って痛いので、会社は屋外に喫煙場所を指定するべきだと思うね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pain</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary>. 

痛い is commonly used to say that some part of the body hurts or feels sore.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: An <reading>eate</reading>r (いた) is someone who eats. But, the eater hurt his mouth. So now it's <vocabulary>painful</vocabulary> to eat.

examples.en: Headache, stomachache, lower back pain... I am full of pains in my body.
examples.ja: 頭痛に胃痛に腰痛に...身体中痛いところだらけです。

examples.en: No, the reason for your headache Ms. Yamane, is simply lack of sleep.
examples.ja: いや、山根さんの頭痛の原因は単に寝不足なだけですよ。

examples.en: Whenever I eat chocolate or drink cocoa, I get a headache.
examples.ja: チョコレートを食べたりココアを飲んだりすると、いつも頭痛におそわれます。

examples.en: I discussed my frequent headaches with my mother.
examples.ja: 頭痛が頻発することを母親に相談しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Head</kanji> <kanji>pain</kanji> is when you have a <vocabulary>headache</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 痛 should be okay. The reading for 頭 isn't one you've learned before, however. Just think, every time you go to the <reading>zoo</reading> (ず) you get a terrible <vocabulary>headache</vocabulary>. Must be the animal feces floating around in the air.

examples.en: I couldn't sleep well last night, so I am very sleepy now.
examples.ja: 昨日はよく眠れなかったので、今すごく眠いです。

examples.en: If I don't drink coffee in the morning, I become sleepy quickly.
examples.ja: 朝コーヒーを飲まないとすぐに眠くなってしまうんです。

examples.en: Oh no, I'm too sleepy.
examples.ja: やばい、眠すぎる。

examples.en: When I was caught in the traffic jam I was also so sleepy that I could barely keep my eyes open.
examples.ja: 渋滞に巻き込まれた時、目も開けていられないくらい眠い状態でもありました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sleep</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sleepy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You're so <vocabulary>sleepy</vocabulary> you can't even remember your own <reading>name</reading> (ねむ).

examples.en: I slept for only three hours yesterday.
examples.ja: 昨日の睡眠時間はたったの三時間でした。

examples.en: What should I do to improve the quality of my sleep?
examples.ja: 睡眠の質を高めるには、どうすればいいんですか？

examples.en: When a baby is born, parents are often sleep deprived for a while.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんが生まれると、親はしばらく睡眠不足になることが多い。

examples.en: He wants to be promoted to management for better pay so he works hard by cutting down on his sleep.
examples.ja: 彼は、給与の良い管理職へ昇格したいがために、睡眠時間を削って一生懸命働いている。

meaning_mnemonic: Feeling <kanji>drowsy</kanji> and like I want to <kanji>sleep</kanji>. I just want to <vocabulary>sleep</vocabulary> so bad.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please put the edge of this table and the edge of that table together.
examples.ja: このテーブルの端とそっちのテーブルの端をくっつけてください。

examples.en: Why do Japanese people start sitting from the end of the row of train seats?
examples.ja: どうして日本人は電車の席の端から座っていくんですか。

examples.en: I've read this book from cover to cover many times, so I have memorized all of its content.
examples.ja: この本は、端から端まで何度も読んだので、内容は全て暗記しています。

examples.en: I saw a big teardrop falling from the corner of Koichi's eye.
examples.ja: 私は大粒の涙がコウイチの目の端からこぼれ落ちるのを見てしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This refers to a literal edge, not a figurative one.

端 refers to the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>end</vocabulary> of something, like the edge of a table, the far end of a bridge, or even the <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary> of a page.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

If you're on <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary>, just eat some <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns to feel better! And if you're going to the edge of the world, hash browns will probably help you make it there too. Hash browns are so useful!

examples.en: The designer presented cutting-edge fashion.
examples.ja: そのデザイナーは、時代の先端をいくファッションを発表した。

examples.en: This game uses a lot of the latest technology.
examples.ja: このゲームには、先端技術がふんだんに使われている。

examples.en: Hehehe... The tip of this katana was poisoned.
examples.ja: フフフ…この刀の先端には毒が付いていたんだよ。

examples.en: The tip of the chopsticks are burnt.
examples.ja: そのお箸の先端は焦げています。

examples.en: Viet-senpai always wears the latest yakuza fashion trends, and he looks cool right?
examples.ja: ビエト先輩って、いつも極道ファッションの流行の先端を行っててカッコイイよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>previous</kanji> (or <kanji>ahead</kanji>) <kanji>edge</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tip</vocabulary> of something, like your finger or your chopsticks. It's also a word used to describe <vocabulary>the latest</vocabulary> (technology, etc), because it's on the <vocabulary>cutting edge</vocabulary>. The tip!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Thinking back now, I was doing it by halves.
examples.ja: 今思うと、すごく中途半端なことをしてたと思います。

examples.en: Even when you learn something halfway, what you have learned won't all go in vain.
examples.ja: 中途半端に物事を学んだとしても、それが全て無だになるわけじゃないよ。

examples.en: That kind of half-hearted attitude is what pisses me off the most.
examples.ja: そういう中途半端な態度が一番ムカつくんだよ。

examples.en: My life may be incomplete, but I would've never dreamt of joining the mafia.
examples.ja: 俺は中途半端な生き方をしてきたかもしれないけど、マフィアに入りたいって思ったことは一度もないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Take the <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>route</kanji>, <kanji>half</kanji> to the <kanji>edge</kanji>. You don't do anything the full way. Just to the middle. Just to the half. Not to the edge. This was really <vocabulary>half finished</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>half assed</vocabulary> of you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぱ at the end is the only tricky part here since that isn't a common reading (or the one you learned before) for the kanji. Just think of your ol' <reading>Pa</reading> (ぱ), who is the biggest half-asser you know.

examples.en: Mr. Takei, you're being quite extreme by quitting the company just because something unpleasant happened, don't you think?
examples.ja: ちょっと嫌なことがあったからって会社を辞めるなんて、武井さんも極端ですねぇ！

examples.en: When you put it in extreme terms, isn't pension basically a system where 'the lucky survivors' make the young people pay for it?
examples.ja: 年金ってさ、めっちゃ極端に言えば「生き残れたラッキーな人に対して、若い人にお金を出させる」仕組みでしょ？

examples.en: I think uniforms are fantastic to be honest. In extreme terms, I believe that everyone wearing the same clothing makes their individual personalities stand out.
examples.ja: 私は制服って素晴らしいと思ってるんです。極端な話、皆が同じ服を着ることで、それぞれの中身の個性が際立つと思うんですよ。

examples.en: You may be able to perform miracles, but I want you to avoid doing extreme things.
examples.ja: 君は奇跡を起こすことができるかもしれない。でも、僕は君には極端なことは避けてもらいたいんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
At the <kanji>extreme</kanji> <kanji>edge</kanji>, which is just the <vocabulary>extreme</vocabulary>.

極端 means something is taken to the extreme without moderation, so it generally has a negative connotation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The water supply has finally resumed.
examples.ja: 水の供給がようやく再開されました。

examples.en: Our maximum priority is to stabilize the supplies.
examples.ja: 最優先事項は供給を安定させることだ。

examples.en: For a stable supply of electricity, it is important to efficiently combine power generation methods such as thermal, hydroelectric, nuclear, and renewable energy sources.
examples.ja: 電力の安定供給には、火力、水力、原子力、再生可能エネルギーなどによる発電を効率的に組み合わせることが重要です。

examples.en: To ensure a stable food supply to the citizens, it is necessary to secure agricultural land and utilize it to the maximum extent possible.
examples.ja: 食料を国民に安定的に供給するには、農地を確保し、それを最大限に有効利用する必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you can <kanji>offer</kanji> a <kanji>salary</kanji> to someone, it means you've got plenty of <vocabulary>supply</vocabulary>. The bigger the salary you can offer, the bigger your supply is, probably. That's why those big tech companies can pay so well — they have an endless supply of paying customers or ad revenue, I guess. 

供給 is a somewhat formal word you'd generally hear in the context of economics — like <vocabulary>supplying</vocabulary> goods, energy, or food where there's demand. You wouldn't use it for art supplies or the food you buy every day.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’m worried about whether or not I can get a raise.
examples.ja: 昇給できるかどうかが気にかかっているんです。

examples.en: I got a raise, but I now have to work more to make up for it.…
examples.ja: 昇給したのはいいんですが、その分もっと働かないといけなくなってしまって…。

examples.en: At my previous company, I received regular raises every year and a bonus twice a year.
examples.ja: 前の会社では、毎年定期昇給があって、賞与も年に2回出ました。

examples.en: When the industry made an economic comeback I applied for a raise, but it didn’t work out.
examples.ja: 業界の景気回復に伴い、昇給を願い出たんだが、うまくいかなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>ascend</kanji> in <kanji>salary</kanji> you get a <vocabulary>pay raise</vocabulary> at work.

Note that this is a relatively formal word to talk about <vocabulary>getting a raise</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It’s strange, I wonder why those countries entered into a peace treaty so suddenly.
examples.ja: どうしてあの国が突然平和友好条約を締結したのか不思議に思うよ。

examples.en: We spent a considerable amount of time to ratify this treaty.
examples.ja: この条約を締結するのにかなり長い時間を費やした。

examples.en: We decided to sign a partnership agreement with the supplier.
examples.ja: 供給元とパートナーシップ協定を締結することにしました。

examples.en: When a foreign country and Japan enter into a treaty, the Diet ratifies the treaty, and then the Cabinet concludes it.
examples.ja: 外国と日本が条約を結ぶ時は、国会が条約を承認し、内閣が条約を締結するんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>tighten</kanji> things up and <kanji>bind</kanji> things together, it's hard to separate them again. That's why this word is used <vocabulary>to conclude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enter into</vocabulary> important agreements, like treaties and contracts.

Note that this word is quite formal, which makes sense, given the contexts it’s usually used in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Did you tightly turn off the gas?
examples.ja: ガスの元栓、ちゃんと締めた？

examples.en: I'm wondering what words would be good to wrap up the speech.
examples.ja: どんな言葉でスピーチを締めるべきか迷っているんだ。

examples.en: Wait a minute. I haven't fastened my seatbelt yet!
examples.ja: ちょっと待って。シートベルト、まだ締めてない！

examples.en: I don't know how to put on a tie, but leave it to me to tighten the screws!
examples.ja: ネクタイの締め方は分からないけど、ネジを締めるのは任せて！

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tighten</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary>, like a screw, or to tie, like a necktie or towel.

締める can also mean <vocabulary>to wrap up</vocabulary> when used in reference to a speech or some other occasion. In Japanese culture, people often 締める a situation with some shared action, like clapping in rhythm to end a celebration or having a final bowl of ramen to close out a night. You call it 締める because it's like you're tying off the event and giving it a sense of closure.
reading_mnemonic: You go <vocabulary>to tighten</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to tie</vocabulary> your captive up, and you realize you don't have anything to do it with. Then you see a sheep standing nearby. Okay. You take the <reading>shee</reading>p (し), pull its wool, and tie the sheep and your captive up together around a tree. Problem solved!

examples.en: He succeeded in obtaining the organizational votes in the presidential election.
examples.ja: 彼は、大統領選挙で組織票をゲットすることに成功した。

examples.en: I heard they finally issued an arrest warrant for that criminal organization.
examples.ja: ついにあの犯罪組織に逮捕状が出たらしいよ。

examples.en: President, what kind of organization do you think a good organization is?
examples.ja: 社長は、いい組織とはどんな組織を指すとお考えですか？

examples.en: I’m Sakuraba, the man responsible for making the promotion decisions for this organization.
examples.ja: 私がこの組織で昇格の決定を担っている桜庭と申します。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>group</kanji> that's <kanji>weave</kanji>d together so tightly with hierarchy and everything else is a little more complicated than a group. It's an <vocabulary>organization</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn that reading for 組, so here's a mnemonic to help: 

You start an <vocabulary>organization</vocabulary> for <reading>so</reading>ap (そ). You're all about soap and making it more effective through your organization. So you call it the Soap Organization for Antiseptic Progress, or S.O.A.P. for short.

examples.en: We mostly weave by machine, but we sometimes weave by hand.
examples.ja: 機械で織ることがほとんどですが、手で織ることもありますよ。

examples.en: I'm weaving a lap blanket with wool from Ms. Sheep.
examples.ja: 羊さんの羊毛で、ひざ掛けを織っているんです。

examples.en: Wow, did you weave this fabric Ken-san?
examples.ja: うわー、この布地、ケンさんが織ったんですか？

examples.en: Lately, my mother has been really into using a handloom to weave carpets.
examples.ja: 私の母親は、最近手織り機でカーペットを織ることにはまっているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>weave</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When you have <vocabulary>to weave</vocabulary> the only thing you can weave is an <reading>O</reading> (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.

examples.en: My stomachache got worse and I was hospitalized, so I spent a month at the hospital.
examples.ja: 胃痛がひどくなって入院し、病院で一ヶ月過ごしました。

examples.en: Please give me the medicine that works well for stomachaches.
examples.ja: 胃痛によく効く薬をください。

examples.en: When you experience severe stomach pain after eating raw fish, please go to the hospital immediately! It could be anisakiasis.
examples.ja: 生魚を食べて激しい胃痛が出た時はすぐに病院へ行ってください！アニサキス症かもしれません。

examples.en: Since I quit smoking my intense stomach aches have also stopped.
examples.ja: 禁煙してから、激しい胃痛も治まっている。

meaning_mnemonic:
When your <kanji>stomach</kanji> <kanji>hurts</kanji> you have yourself a little <vocabulary>stomachache</vocabulary>.

Try to remember this isn't for general abdominal pain. 胃痛 is specifically for pain or discomfort in the stomach (the internal organ) — a literal stomachache.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You are getting a little fat around the belly, aren’t you?
examples.ja: お前ちょっと腹が出てきたんじゃねぇか？

examples.en: Ms. Shimazaki was holding her belly with laughter.
examples.ja: 島崎さんは腹をかかえて笑っていました。

examples.en: These days, I have been bothered by my beer belly, so I finally decided to go on a diet.
examples.ja: 最近ビール腹が気になって、とうとうダイエットをすることにしました。

examples.en: I've been experiencing stomach pain for quite some time now.
examples.ja: ここ最近、ずっと腹が痛いんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
If anyone tries to touch your <kanji>belly</kanji>, that's <reading>hara</reading>ssment (はら). Unless you're cool with it, obviously. But if you're not, make sure to yell "harassment!" when they touch your belly. You should also shout what kind of harassment it is: 腹ハラ (腹 harassment).

Note: This word will often get rendaku'd when it's combined with other vocab, like in ビールばら (beer belly) or 別ばら (separate stomach for dessert).

examples.en: It hurts just to think about seppuku, doesn’t it?
examples.ja: 切腹とか考えるだけで痛いよね。

examples.en: How did Japanese samurai warriors come to commit seppuku?
examples.ja: どうして日本の武士は切腹をするようになったのでしょうか？

examples.en: Yesterday, I dreamed that I became a samurai and committed ritual suicide.
examples.ja: 昨日、サムライになって切腹する夢を見た。

examples.en: The old samurai insisted on committing ritual suicide.
examples.ja: その年老いた武士は、切腹をすることに固執した。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>cut</kanji> your <kanji>abdomen</kanji> you are committing <vocabulary>seppuku</vocabulary>. It will help if you already know the word "seppuku" from English, since it's also the reading here.

切腹 is a form of <vocabulary>ritual suicide</vocabulary> by self-inflicted disembowelment, often performed by samurai to restore honor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But it's got shortening and rendaku going on, so you have to remember those if you want to get it right. Or just know the word seppuku already since it's pretty popular. That works too.

examples.en: You should call her before visiting.
examples.ja: 家を訪ねる前に、電話してみた方がいいよ。

examples.en: Nobuko, don't open the door even when a stranger visits the house.
examples.ja: 信子ちゃん、知らない人が訪ねてきてもドアを開けたらダメよ。

examples.en: Someday, I want to take a trip to visit the natural beauty of Canada using a camper van.
examples.ja: いつか、キャンピングカーを使って、カナダの自然を訪ねる旅がしたいんです。

examples.en: I visited a truant student every day after school.
examples.ja: 私は、放課後毎日、不登校の生徒を訪ねました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>visit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You want <vocabulary>to visit</vocabulary> your friend <reading>Taz</reading> (たず), the Tasmanian Devil. He's your best bro, so imagine visiting him and having a good time and saying you're going to visit him again.

examples.en: Is there something that got on your nerves when I visited you the other day?
examples.ja: この間の訪問の際、何かお気に触るようなことをしてしまいましたか？

examples.en: Don't you have a home-visit care service that is a bit cheaper?
examples.ja: もうちょっと安い訪問サービスはないんですか？

examples.en: Home visits are for teachers to visit students' homes, observe the home environment, and have conversations with parents.
examples.ja: 家庭訪問は、先生が生徒の家庭を訪ね、家庭環境を観察し、保護者と話すためのものです。

examples.en: In Japan, you usually can't get all your dental treatment done in just one visit.
examples.ja: 日本では、通常歯医者に一回の訪問で治療を済ませてもらうことはできません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>visit</kanji> <kanji>problem</kanji> is when someone makes <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary>, because you're the type of person who doesn't like visitors, since they're usually so inconsiderate and you have to feed them. That's why <vocabulary>a visit</vocabulary> is a visit problem.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm sorry, but my parents have told me not to lend money to people.
examples.ja: すみませんが、人にお金を貸すな、と親に言われているんです。

examples.en: Renting out apartments or houses isn't as easy as you might think. Depending on the tenant, it can become really stressful.
examples.ja: アパートや家を貸すのって、思ってるほど楽じゃないよ。テナントさんによって、ほんとストレスになるんだから。

examples.en: I guess it can't be avoided. Just this time, I'll lend you a hand.
examples.ja: しょうがねーな。今回だけ、手を貸してやるよ。

examples.en: "Can you lend me your car?" "Absolutely not. You don’t have a license yet."
examples.ja: 「君の車を貸してくれない？」「絶対にだめだよ。まだ免許持ってないじゃないか。」
