meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lend</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Allow me <vocabulary>to lend</vocabulary> you some advice. The reading you learned from the kanji can be used here.

examples.en: Our company chartered a plane and we went to Bermuda.
examples.ja: 会社で飛行機を貸し切りにしてバミューダまで行きました。

examples.en: Tokyo Disneyland sometimes has days reserved for celebrities only.
examples.ja: 東京ディズニーランドは時々芸能人貸し切りになる日があります。

examples.en: The inn has a private hot spring.
examples.ja: この宿には、貸し切りの温泉があります。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>lend</kanji>ing gets <kanji>cut</kanji> right away when you make a <vocabulary>private reservation</vocabulary>.

貸し切り means reserving a space exclusively, like renting out a restaurant for a birthday party or chartering a bus, cruise, or jet.
reading_mnemonic: It's the reading of 貸す and 切る put together. Know those two readings and you know this one as well. Sometimes you'll see this word as 貸切り or 貸切 as well.

examples.en: I pressed him to pay back the money, but he ran away.
examples.ja: 彼に金を返すよう迫ったが、逃げられてしまった。

examples.en: If you only look at the surface, you will never close in on the essence of the matter.
examples.ja: 表面的なことだけを見ていては、物事の本質に迫ることはできません。

examples.en: It appears that danger is imminent.
examples.ja: どうやら危険が迫っているようですね。

examples.en: I am currently being pressed to make a big decision.
examples.ja: 私は今、大きな決断を迫られています

examples.en: I was quite surprised to see Koichi's face, which was five meters away from me a second ago, suddenly looming right in front of me.
examples.ja: 一秒前には五メートル先にあったコウイチの顔が急に目前に迫ってきてかなりびっくりした。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>urge</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.

At its core, 迫る means <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary>, like a deadline or danger drawing near. This idea extends to urging someone because it's like you're coming really close to them, <vocabulary>to press</vocabulary> them into action.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Do you prefer <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary> people to do something, or <vocabulary>to press</vocabulary> them to do it? It depends on how you want <vocabulary>to approach</vocabulary> them. But it's all <reading>sema</reading>ntics (せま) because they're basically the same.

examples.en: For some reason, I feel a tight pressure on my chest since last weekend.
examples.ja: 何故か週末から胸が圧迫される感じがあるんです。

examples.en: My friend Hanako is practicing for stress interviews in order to pass the test to become a broadcaster.
examples.ja: 友達の花子ちゃんは、アナウンサー試験に合格するために圧迫面接の練習をしています。

examples.en: Sending money to my son is putting a strain on our finances.
examples.ja: 息子への仕送りが家計を圧迫しています。

examples.en: I gave up my dream to become an astronaut because I couldn’t stand the pressure.
examples.ja: 圧迫に耐えないので、宇宙飛行士になる夢を諦めた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>pressure</kanji> is <kanji>urge</kanji>d upon you. It's the <vocabulary>pressure</vocabulary>, so much pressure!

圧迫 refers to a tight pressure caused by strong compression, or to the act of pressing down itself. Figuratively, it can also mean <vocabulary>constriction</vocabulary>, like tuition fees putting a strain on a household budget, or <vocabulary>oppression</vocabulary>, such as people being subjugated.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The あつ turns into a small っ, and はく goes to ぱく.

examples.en: I think all people should learn the history of persecution and discrimination in the world.
examples.ja: 全ての人々が、世界の迫害と差別の歴史を学ぶべきだと思います。

examples.en: We fled to this country because there was a possibility of persecution if we stayed in our homeland.
examples.ja: 私達は自国にいると迫害を受ける可能性があったので、この国に逃げて来たんです。

examples.en: The Rohingya refugees are referred to as "the most persecuted minority in the world.”
examples.ja: ロヒンギャ難民は、「世界で最も迫害された少数民族」と呼ばれています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Someone has an <kanji>urge</kanji> to <kanji>damage</kanji> things. If that person wants to harm you, you might be facing <vocabulary>persecution</vocabulary>.

As you might guess, this word is quite formal.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: His situation must be pretty dire.
examples.ja: ヤツの状況はかなり切迫しているはずです。

examples.en: With an urgent expression on his face, Koichi said, "I need to go to the bathroom right now, or it's going to be bad.”
examples.ja: コウイチは切迫した表情で、「俺、今すぐトイレに行かなきゃヤバイんだ」と言った。

examples.en: I’m facing an imminent crisis so I need to borrow money from the yakuza.
examples.ja: ヤクザからお金を借りなければいけないという切迫した危機に直面している。

examples.en: I was hospitalized for three weeks due to threatened premature labor, and being hospitalized for such conditions is really difficult.
examples.ja: 切迫早産で三週間入院したけど、切迫の入院って、本当に辛いんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
We're <kanji>cut</kanji> right down to the end, reaching that <kanji>urge</kanji> position where <vocabulary>urgency</vocabulary> is so strong.

切迫 is used to describe the tension in a situation where a time limit is <vocabulary>drawing near</vocabulary>, or to describe something bad or dangerous as <vocabulary>impending</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.

examples.en: My mother often gets lost.
examples.ja: 私の母はよく道に迷うんです。

examples.en: I'm torn between buying a Mario figurine or a Luigi figurine.
examples.ja: マリオの人形とルイージの人形、どちらを買おうか迷っています。

examples.en: There will be a bunch of people there I don't know, so to be honest, I'm still not sure whether I'll go.
examples.ja: 知らない人がたくさんいるだろうし、正直まだ行くかどうか迷ってるんだよね。

examples.en: I'm not sure if I should buy unsweetened coffee.
examples.ja: 無糖珈琲を買おうかどうか迷っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>astray</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to go astray</vocabulary> (because you don't just "to astray" now do you?). You can use it if you ever happen <vocabulary>to get lost</vocabulary>. 

Beyond physically getting lost, 迷う is also for times when you waver between different choices or hesitate to take a decisive step.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you are going <vocabulary>to go astray</vocabulary>, one way to do it would be to eat wayyyy too much <reading>mayo</reading> (まよ). I can't think of a worse way to go astray, personally.

examples.en: I heard that at Disneyland, they don't broadcast for lost children.
examples.ja: ディズニーランドでは迷子の放送がないそうですよ。

examples.en: Even Japanese people often get lost at Shinjuku Station.
examples.ja: 日本人でも、新宿駅で迷子になる人は多い。

examples.en: I wasn't attentive, and I almost got lost at Universal Studios Japan.
examples.ja: ボーッとしてたら、USJで迷子になりかけた。

examples.en: I was just trying to find the parents of a lost child, but I was accused of attempted kidnapping.
examples.ja: 迷子の子どもの両親を探してあげようとしていただけなのに、誘拐未遂で起訴されてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
After going <kanji>astray</kanji>, the <kanji>child</kanji> becomes a <vocabulary>lost child</vocabulary>. Let's help them find their way home.

Keep in mind that 迷子 isn't only for lost children; it applies to anyone who's lost, such as a <vocabulary>lost person</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>stray animal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 迷 is an exceptional reading. The ご comes from こ. Think of the まい as the child asking: "Where is <reading>my</reading> (まい) mommy???"

examples.en: The map for the maze is hidden somewhere.
examples.ja: どこかに、迷路の地図が隠されています。

examples.en: Nobody found their way out of the maze.
examples.ja: 誰一人としてその迷路の出口を見つけることができませんでした。

examples.en: Haruko and Akiko compete against each other at a corn maze every year. I wonder which one will win this year.
examples.ja: 春子ちゃんと秋子ちゃんは毎年トウモロコシばたけの迷路で競争しているんだけど、今年はどっちが勝つかな。

examples.en: My son loves mazes.
examples.ja: 私の息子は迷路が大好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>road</kanji> where you're <kanji>astray</kanji> is a road that goes all around in different ways, tricking you and making you lost. This is a <vocabulary>maze</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Anyhow, it's probably a kind of superstition.
examples.ja: どうせ迷信の一種でしょう。

examples.en: I don't believe in the superstition and kept using a cracked mirror up until now.
examples.ja: 私は迷信を信じないので、今でも割れた鏡を使っています。

examples.en: It's discriminatory to say that old people are more likely to believe in superstitions.
examples.ja: 年寄りは迷信を信じやすいというのは差別だ。

meaning_mnemonic: Led <kanji>astray</kanji> in what you <kanji>believe</kanji> by all these <vocabulary>superstition</vocabulary>s. These superstitions will lead you astray, don't believe them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I hope I will be released from the hospital soon.
examples.ja: すぐに退院することができるといいんだけど。

examples.en: We do not know yet when he will be able to leave the hospital.
examples.ja: いつ退院することができるのかはまだ分かりません。

examples.en: Ms. Murata's mother left the hospital six hours after she had her baby.
examples.ja: 村田さんのお母さんは、赤ちゃんを産んだ後、六時間で退院しました。

examples.en: When Dad gets discharged from the hospital, let's celebrate.
examples.ja: お父さんが退院したらみんなでお祝いをしよう。

meaning_mnemonic: Time to <kanji>retreat</kanji> from the <kanji>institution</kanji>. Basically, you are leaving an institution, particularly institutions like hospitals, asylums, etc. When you are leaving one of these places, it means you are <vocabulary>to be discharged</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why don’t you leave school early with me?
examples.ja: 一緒に学校を早退しない？

examples.en: Because I had a severe stomachache, I left work early and went to see a doctor.
examples.ja: 激しい胃痛があったので、会社を早退して医者に行きました。

examples.en: I submitted an early leave form at work, but it doesn't seem to be approved yet.
examples.ja: 会社に早退届を出したのですが、まだ受理されていないようです。

examples.en: I left school early and my friends said I was cheating. Is it wrong to leave early?
examples.ja: 学校を早退したら、友達にずるいって言われたんだけど、早退は悪いことなの？

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>early</kanji> <kanji>retreat</kanji> means that you <vocabulary>leave early</vocabulary>.

Note that 早退 means leaving school or work earlier than usual. It's not used for leaving hangouts or parties early.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Can you stop by a grocery store and buy some tofu on your way home?
examples.ja: 途中でスーパーによっておとうふを買って来てちょうだい。

examples.en: I was in the middle of eating lunch when I got a phone call.
examples.ja: 昼ご飯を食べてる途中で、電話がかかってきた。

examples.en: Oh, I stopped playing that game halfway through.
examples.ja: あ、そのゲーム、途中で止めちゃったんだよね。

examples.en: That painting is still only half done.
examples.ja: その絵はまだ途中です。

examples.en: "Can you come over right now?" "Sure, I’m actually on my way now." "Huh? Do you know where you’re going?" "Nope, I don’t."
examples.ja: 「今すぐに来られますか？」「ええ。今向かっている途中です。」「え？ということは、場所をご存知なんですね？」「いいえ、分かりません。」

meaning_mnemonic:
If you're on a <kanji>route</kanji>, right in the <kanji>middle</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>on the way</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>en route</vocabulary>.

途中 can also be used figuratively to say you're <vocabulary>in the middle of</vocabulary> doing something or something is <vocabulary>half done</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How are you planning to arrest them?
examples.ja: どうやって逮捕するつもりですか？

examples.en: We finally arrested the culprit.
examples.ja: ついに犯人を逮捕した。

examples.en: I've never been arrested before.
examples.ja: これまでに逮捕されたことはありません。

examples.en: You should be careful because the criminal is still free.
examples.ja: 犯人はまだ逮捕されてないみたいだから、気を付けた方がいいよ。

examples.en: If you don’t leave now, I’ll arrest you for violating laws against interfering with a public servant in the line of duty.
examples.ja: もし今この場を去らなければ、公務執行妨害で逮捕するぞ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 逮捕 is an "arrest" or "capture"? This is the verb version, and it is <vocabulary>to arrest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to capture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also be helpful to know the word 逮捕 already as well.

examples.en: I just don't like the way that bastard speaks.
examples.ja: あの野郎の物の言い方が気に入らねぇんだよ。

examples.en: The guys were making a ruckus at the party.
examples.ja: パーティーでは野郎どもがどんちゃんさわぎをしていた。

examples.en: You rascal, how dare you!
examples.ja: この野郎、よくもやったな！

examples.en: That bastard got promoted to sales manager. I’m sick to my stomach.
examples.ja: あのクソ野郎がセールス・マネージャーに昇進するなんて本当に気に食わねぇ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Ugh, that <kanji>field</kanji> <kanji>guy</kanji>. He's the worst. Always in the fields, making us look bad, quite the <vocabulary>bastard</vocabulary>. Really though, he's just this guy, but for some reason I sometimes don't like him.

While 野郎 can be a casual term for a man, it's usually used to insult or show annoyance towards someone. So it's best to avoid using it unless you're really sure it's okay!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am having trouble because my kid loses his shoes quickly.
examples.ja: 子供がすぐ靴をなくすから困っているんです。

examples.en: Perhaps it is because my walking style is bad, but my shoes get worn out within a year of buying them.
examples.ja: 歩き方が悪いせいか、靴を買っても一年たたないうちにはきつぶしてしまう。

examples.en: It's time to get new shoes.
examples.ja: そろそろ新しい靴を買わなきゃ。

examples.en: "Ah, my feet are killing me." "Told you so! That’s why I told you to wear more comfortable shoes."
examples.ja: 「ああ、足が棒だよ。痛くて死にそう。」「言わんこっちゃない。だから、もっと歩きやすい靴を履けって最初に言ったじゃないか。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Huzzah!

examples.en: It says three pairs of socks for 500 yen. That’s so cheap!
examples.ja: 靴下三足で五百円だって！めっちゃ安いっ。

examples.en: I don't like nylon socks because they are slippery.
examples.ja: ナイロンの靴下はすべるから好きじゃない。

examples.en: Hey, did you know? In English, those socks that Santa Claus fills with gifts on Christmas are called "Christmas stockings"!
examples.ja: ねえ、知ってた？クリスマスにサンタさんがプレゼントを入れてくれる靴下のこと、英語では 「クリスマスストッキングズ」って言うんだって！

examples.en: I tried to reach the top shelf to get a pair of pink socks, but I wasn’t tall enough.
examples.ja: ピンクの靴下を取ろうと一番上の棚に手を伸ばしたが、背丈が足りずに届かなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: What's <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>shoes</kanji>? Your <vocabulary>socks</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: There is a famous shoe store in front of Mr. Takahashi's house.
examples.ja: 高橋さんの家の前には有名な靴屋さんがあります。

examples.en: We always buy shoes from the same shoe shop.
examples.ja: うちは、いつも同じ靴屋で靴を買うんだよ。

examples.en: Don't you have to go all the way to Italy to study abroad, just because you want to work as a craftsman in a shoemaker's shop?
examples.ja: 靴屋で職人として働きたいからってわざわざイタリアまで留学しなくてもよくない？

examples.en: I was offered a job at the shoe store, but I politely declined.
examples.ja: 靴屋での仕事に内定が出たが、丁重にお断りさせてもらったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>shoes</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is one that sells shoes. It's a <vocabulary>shoe store</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoe shop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Koichi, you always wear Pikachu rain boots on rainy days, don't you?
examples.ja: コウイチはいつも雨の日はピカチュウの長靴をはいてくるよね。

examples.en: I always thought rain boots are for kids, but these days, there are fashionable rain boots for adults too, aren't there?
examples.ja: 長靴って子供のものだけかと思ってたんだけど、最近じゃ大人用のお洒落な長靴も売ってるんだね。

examples.en: While laying in his hospital bed, he decided he would get a nice pair of riding boots for his wife the next day.
examples.ja: 病院のベッドに横になりながら、彼は明日妻にいい乗馬用の長靴を買ってやろうと思った。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Long</kanji> <kanji>shoes</kanji> aren't long in that the feet part are long (that wouldn't make sense). Instead, the top part is long to keep you dry when it's raining. Yes, these are <vocabulary>rain boots</vocabulary>.

In modern Japanese, 長靴 is most commonly used to mean rain boots or <vocabulary>rubber boots</vocabulary>. It can occasionally mean <vocabulary>riding boots</vocabulary> as well. But if you're referring to fashion boots or boots in general, you can just call them ブーツ.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. Double kun'yomi, so think along the lines of 長い and 靴 getting added together. 靴 is the reading you learned with the kanji, however. It also gets rendaku'd.

examples.en: That man was a bad influence on all of us.
examples.ja: あの男がみんなに悪影響を与えたんだよ。

examples.en: She cried as she realized that her bad influence filtered down to her children.
examples.ja: 悪影響が自分の子どもにまで及んでいたことに気が付き、彼女は泣き出した。

examples.en: YouTube is convenient, but we need to be careful because some videos may be harmful to children.
examples.ja: YouTubeは便利だけど、子供に悪影響が出そうな動画もあるから注意が必要だよね。

examples.en: I think the negative impact that smartphones have had on humanity is immeasurable.
examples.ja: スマホが人類にもたらした悪影響は計り知れないと思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: 影響 is "influence," so an <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>influence</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad influence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I had some stomach trouble and that forced me to retire.
examples.ja: 胃病のせいで、隠居することになりました。

examples.en: My father is retired in a farming village.
examples.ja: 私の父は農村で隠居しています。

examples.en: I was fed up with my working life, so I decided to sell all my stocks and go into retirement.
examples.ja: 社会人生活に嫌気がさしたので、持っている株を全て売って隠居することにしました。

meaning_mnemonic:
隠居 is "retirement". Make that a verb and you have <vocabulary>to retire</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be retired</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go into retirement</vocabulary>.

Like 隠居, this word emphasizes life after retiring, and usually implies having a quiet, maybe secluded, lifestyle. It's a bit of an old-fashioned word, but you'll still see it in modern writing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you have any recommendations for a good izakaya?
examples.ja: おすすめの居酒屋とかってありますか？

examples.en: That izakaya manager is really funny.
examples.ja: あの居酒屋の店長、本当に面白いよね。

examples.en: Cheaper chain izakayas are more relaxing than upscale izakayas.
examples.ja: 高級居酒屋よりも安いチェーン居酒屋の方がほっとする。

examples.en: The door opened and an old woman walked into the izakaya by herself.
examples.ja: 扉が開き、居酒屋の中に老婆が一人ぼっちで入ってきた。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>alive</kanji> <kanji>alcohol</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a place that serves a lot of alcohol. In Japan, these places are often <vocabulary>izakaya</vocabulary>. If you don't already know what an izakaya is, you can consider it to be a casual <vocabulary>Japanese Style Bar</vocabulary>.

An izakaya is a pub or tavern where you can enjoy drinks and tasty bar food like yakitori and gyoza, usually at quite affordable prices. Cheers!
reading_mnemonic:
The readings here are all kun'yomi, but this is the first time you've seen the さか reading for 酒, which rendaku then turns into ざか here. If you know what an izakaya is already, you can probably remember the reading, but if not here's a mnemonic to help:

When you need recommendations for a good <vocabulary>izakaya</vocabulary> (a <vocabulary>Japanese style bar</vocabulary>), you ask your friend <reading>Zacha</reading>ry (ざか). He knows all the best spots. You even call him Izakaya Zachary. He doesn't like that, but too bad. In your mind, Zachary will always be tied to Japanese style bars.

examples.en: My daughter lacks physical strength compared to the other girls at her age.
examples.ja: 同じ年の女の子と比較すると、私の娘は体力があまりありません。

examples.en: Let us now compare the two sets of data.
examples.ja: では、次に二つのデータを比較してみましょう。

examples.en: Stop comparing me to your ex-girlfriend!
examples.ja: 元カノと比較するの、やめてよ！

meaning_mnemonic: 比較 is <vocabulary>comparison</vocabulary>. So, verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to compare</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.

examples.en: I plan to wear a yukata to the fireworks display.
examples.ja: 花火大会には浴衣で行く予定です。

examples.en: Yukata can be rented at that ryokan.
examples.ja: あの旅館では浴衣がレンタルできます。

examples.en: Wait, Kana-chan, you can put on a yukata by yourself?
examples.ja: え、カナちゃんって自分で浴衣が着れるの？

examples.en: She clung to her old ways of thinking and wore a yukata instead of pajamas every night.
examples.ja: 彼女は自分の古い考え方にしがみついて、毎晩パジャマの代わりに浴衣を着て過ごした。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>bathe</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> are clothes you wear to and from the bath. They're your <vocabulary>yukata</vocabulary>.

浴衣 originated as robes worn in a steam bath (that explains the kanji), but these days people mostly wear them at summer festivals or traditional Japanese inns. Be careful not to mix up 浴衣 with 着物, which are much more formal and elaborate!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = ゆかた.

examples.en: How long are you sleeping? Get up now and get ready!
examples.ja: いつまで寝てるの！早く起きて支度しなさい！！

examples.en: Please call me when you've gotten ready for school.
examples.ja: 学校へ行く支度ができたら呼んでください。

examples.en: Mom is preparing dinner in the kitchen and dad is making arrangements for a trip in his room.
examples.ja: 母は台所で夕飯の支度を、父は部屋で旅行の支度をしています。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>support</kanji> yourself to some <kanji>degree</kanji>, you need <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary>. Doing your hair and makeup in the morning supports your presentation to some extent, right? 

This is another word for "preparation" besides 準備 and 用意. They’re all similar, but 支度 is usually used in personal contexts, such as 身支度 (getting dressed) or 旅支度 (<vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary> for a trip).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 度 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

To remember your morning <vocabulary>preparation</vocabulary>, you set up a <reading>tack</reading> (たく) board covered in reminders in every room of your house. With helpful notes tacked up everywhere, <vocabulary>getting ready</vocabulary> should be as easy as ever.

examples.en: "Where are you?" "I'm in the living room now."
examples.ja: 「今、どこ？」「え、今、居間だよ」

examples.en: Dad is watching TV in the living room.
examples.ja: 父は居間でテレビを観ています。

examples.en: You took off your socks in the living room and left them there.
examples.ja: 居間に靴下が脱ぎっぱなしになってるよ。

examples.en: Even when I said, "Dinner is ready!" nobody wanted to move from the sitting room.
examples.ja: 「ごはんできたよー！」と言っても、だれも居間から動こうとしなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
A room that comes <kanji>alive</kanji> in <kanji>interval</kanji>s is your <vocabulary>living room</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sitting room</vocabulary>. You don't spend all your time in there, so it can only be alive sometimes.

Note that 居間 is a little old-fashioned. These days, the more common word for a living room is リビングルーム.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I get a pain in my lower back when I bend down.
examples.ja: 屈むと腰が痛いんです。

examples.en: I bent down and put on my socks.
examples.ja: 屈んで靴下をはきました。

examples.en: I suddenly felt a tightening in my chest and leaned over.
examples.ja: 急に胸が締めつけられているような感覚におそわれ、屈んでしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>yield</kanji>, and 屈む means <vocabulary>to bend down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to crouch</vocabulary>. After all, bending down and crouching are sort of like yielding to gravity, don’t you think?

屈む refers to the act of lowering your head or body, so it can also mean <vocabulary>to duck</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to squat</vocabulary> depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You always have <vocabulary>to bend down</vocabulary> to get into your <reading>car ga</reading>rage (かが) because you’re just too tall. You have <vocabulary>to crouch</vocabulary> just to get inside your car garage! Let’s hope you can find a bigger one someday.

examples.en: That celebrity doesn't mention retirement at all.
examples.ja: そのタレントは引退を全く口にしない。

examples.en: I heard that boxers tend to gain weight after retiring.
examples.ja: ボクサーは引退後太ることが多いらしい。

examples.en: I intend to retire from the Youtube world soon.
examples.ja: そろそろYoutube界を引退しようと考えてるんだ。

examples.en: Tomorrow a senior member of my basketball team is retiring from the team.
examples.ja: 明日はバスケ部の先輩が引退する日だ.

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>pull</kanji> yourself back and <kanji>retreat</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>retiring</vocabulary>. At some point in everyone's lives you just can't do it anymore and it's time to take your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary>.

This word focuses on the moment of retiring. It's often used to mean <vocabulary>withdrawing from public life</vocabulary>, when someone ends their career in a particular field, like when celebrities or pro athletes retire. It can also be used for students who stop extracurricular activities like clubs and sports teams ahead of graduation, often to study for their exams.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 引 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Now that you're <vocabulary>retiring</vocabulary>, you decide to go and spend your <vocabulary>retirement</vocabulary> at an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). Inns are great places to spend your retirement because everything is done for you, and you can just sit back and relax!

examples.en: I don’t have the courage to hand him the present.
examples.ja: プレゼントを手渡す勇気はありません。

examples.en: Koichi suddenly handed the socks that he already used over to me.
examples.ja: コウイチは突然、使用済みの靴下を手渡してきた。

examples.en: I'd like to see you in person and hand-deliver it to you, if possible.
examples.ja: できれば直接会って、手渡しで渡したいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 渡す means "to hand over?" Well you can use your actual <kanji>hand</kanji> <vocabulary>to hand over</vocabulary> something too!
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Speaking English fluently is so cool! I admire it.
examples.ja: 英語ペラペラ、かっこいいよね！憧れる。

examples.en: I admire that senpai.
examples.ja: あの先輩に憧れているんです。

examples.en: Many young people are attracted to the idea of city life and come to Tokyo.
examples.ja: 都会生活に憧れて上京してくる若者は多い。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>long for</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to long for</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to yearn after</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: In reality, there are many things where logic alone will not work.
examples.ja: 現実には理屈だけじゃ通用しないことは山ほどある。

examples.en: I like hockey without reason.
examples.ja: ホッケーは理屈抜きで好きなんです。

examples.en: There are many things that you understand logically, but are difficult when you actually try to do them, right?
examples.ja: 理屈で分かっていても、実際にやってみると難しいことってたくさんありますよね？

examples.en: You're always overcomplicating things with your fancy reasoning; you're quite obnoxious.
examples.ja: 小難しい理屈ばっかりこねて、本当に嫌な人ね。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Reason</kanji> <kanji>yield</kanji>s to <vocabulary>logic</vocabulary> and more <vocabulary>reasoning</vocabulary>.

理屈 can be neutral, but it often has negative connotations too, like when it refers to an <vocabulary>argument</vocabulary> that contains questionable logic, pretexts, or too much pedantry.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My stomach aches from stress.
examples.ja: ストレスで、胃がキリキリします。

examples.en: For the first time in my life, I had a gastroscopy.
examples.ja: 人生で初めて胃カメラを飲んだ。

examples.en: What was the name of the character with the trait of having a weak stomach?
examples.ja: あの胃が弱い設定のキャラクター、何て名前だっけ？

examples.en: I ate too much cake and bacon, and they've been heavy on my stomach.
examples.ja: ケーキとベーコンの食べ過ぎで胃がもたれています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Just keep in mind 胃 is specifically for the internal organ "stomach," not for the general abdominal area "stomach."
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Oh, did you come all the way here alone without anyone accompanying you?
examples.ja: ほう、誰も従えず、一人でここまで来たのかい？

examples.en: The singer came with three bodyguards in tow.
examples.ja: その歌手は三人のボディガードを従えてやってきた。

examples.en: At the age of twenty, he had already become a company president leading over a hundred employees.
examples.ja: 二十才の時には、すでに百人の社員を従える社長になっていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>obey</kanji>, but the verb meaning is a bit different. In most contexts, it often just means <vocabulary>to be accompanied by</vocabulary> someone or <vocabulary>to have in tow</vocabulary>. To help you remember this, imagine that everyone you're accompanied by obeys you! You're sort of their leader, so you go everywhere with them following in tow.

従える is a relatively formal word that's often used in literature.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading with 従う. Remember it?

examples.en: Can I leave my hairstyle decisions to you?
examples.ja: ヘアスタイルは、お任せでお願いできますか？

examples.en: I made a reservation for a 5000-yen omakase special.
examples.ja: 五千円のお任せコースで予約したよ。

examples.en: If you need legal advice, you can count on me!
examples.ja: 法律の相談は、私共にお任せください！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word comes from 任せる, but without the る on the end it's a noun. You also have the honorific お on the beginning, which is a clue that you're addressing someone else. So you're entrusting something to the person you're talking to, and this means <vocabulary>leaving decisions to someone else</vocabulary>. This is used a lot in restaurants, where it means <vocabulary>chef's choice</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>omakase</vocabulary>. In other words, you're leaving the choice of food to the chef.

It can be used in other contexts, too, like if you leave your haircut up to your stylist or a flower arrangement up to the florist, or even if you follow the recommended program at the gym.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading with the word 任せる, so I'll leave this one to you.

examples.en: This is an objective fact.
examples.ja: これは客観的事実です。

examples.en: Objectively speaking, what you just said is not right.
examples.ja: 客観的に見て、今の発言はおかしいです。

examples.en: Without objective data, it lacks persuasiveness.
examples.ja: 客観的なデータがないと説得力に欠けてしまいます。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 主観的 meaning "subjective"? This is the counterpart to that. And since <kanji>guest</kanji>s' and customers' <kanji>view</kanji>s are always objectively right, this means <vocabulary>objective</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please unify the writing style into the desu-masu form.
examples.ja: 文体は、です・ます調に統一してください。

examples.en: First, let's consolidate the evaluation criteria.
examples.ja: まずは評価の基準を統一しましょう。

examples.en: Who were the three individuals who aimed to unify the country during the Warring States period?
examples.ja: 戦国時代に天下統一を目指した3人は誰でしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>unite</kanji> as <kanji>one</kanji> is to achieve total <vocabulary>unity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>uniformity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, it uses a reading for 一 that you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You dream about <vocabulary>unity</vocabulary> so often that it <reading>eats</reading> (いつ) away at you. Thoughts of uniting your country occupy you day and night, but you can't let them consume you.

examples.en: Dedicating time to studying is a very good thing.
examples.ja: 勉強に時間を費やすのはとても良いことです。

examples.en: I'm trying to be careful not to waste time and effort.
examples.ja: ムダな時間と労力を費やさないよう、気をつけています。

examples.en: The man spent most of his living expenses on pachinko.
examples.ja: 男は、生活費のほとんどをパチンコに費やしてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
Turn <kanji>expense</kanji> into a verb and you get <vocabulary>to spend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expend</vocabulary>. Or, in some cases, <vocabulary>to waste</vocabulary>.

In addition to spending money, 費やす can be used to refer to spending other resources like time, effort, energy, and emotions.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Just as you're about <vocabulary>to spend</vocabulary> some money, a familiar sound comes from inside your wallet: "<reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい)!" It's the little bird that lives inside your wallet and angrily tweets at you whenever you're about <vocabulary>to waste</vocabulary> money on something you don't need. Maybe you should listen to the bird tweeting from inside your wallet a little more.

examples.en: It is difficult to meet the diverse needs of our customers.
examples.ja: お客様の多種多様なニーズに応えるのは難しい。

examples.en: I'm flattered, but I can't reciprocate your feelings. I'm sorry.
examples.ja: うれしいけど、あなたの気持ちには応えられないよ。ごめんね。

examples.en: We did our best to meet the expectations of the president.
examples.ja: 社長からの期待に、全力で応えた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>respond</kanji>, and this is also <vocabulary>to respond to</vocabulary>, but often in the sense of trying <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to live up to</vocabulary> some expectation, need, or other feelings.

Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some example usages of this!
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, but it shares a reading (and some similarities in meaning) with 答える, so just try to think of that vocab in relation to this one!

examples.en: Excuse me, could I get a hand wipe, please?
examples.ja: すいません、お手拭きをもらえますか？

examples.en: Oh, feel free to use this hand wipe!
examples.ja: あ、よかったらこのお手拭き使って！

examples.en: When I sit down at a restaurant, I first wipe my hands with a hand wipe.
examples.ja: レストランで席につくと、まずお手拭きで手を拭きます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>hand</kanji> and the noun version of 拭く (to wipe). Put the two together and you get a <vocabulary>hand wipe</vocabulary>!

お手拭き refers to a <vocabulary>wet hand towel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wet napkin</vocabulary> used for cleaning your hands, often provided at restaurants in Japan before a meal.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this uses all kun'yomi. So just put together the kun'yomis of 手 and 拭き (from the verb 拭く) with an honorary お and you're good to go!

examples.en: We're getting further into autumn, and the season for tasty mushrooms is just around the corner now, isn't it?
examples.ja: 秋も更けて、もうすぐキノコが美味しいシーズンですね。

examples.en: And so the night wore on.
examples.ja: こうして夜は更けて行ったのでした。

examples.en: I was writing my kid's name and drawing a picture of his face on each of his diapers for daycare, and before I knew it, it had gotten really late into the night.
examples.ja: 保育園用のオムツ一つ一つに子供の名前と似顔絵をかいてたら、すっかり夜が更けちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means renew, but the verb meaning is a little different. This means to grow late, to wear on, or to deepen. Think of it this way: you only renew stuff that's not new, after time has worn on a bit — your streaming subscriptions, your driver's license, your marriage vows. And with each renewal you feel the passage of time a little more deeply… You'll see 更ける more often in writing, usually in reference to night or autumn, as in 夜が更ける (the night grows late) and 秋が更ける (autumn deepens).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

As it starts <vocabulary>to grow late</vocabulary>, you turn into a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). You ever get increasingly delirious and giggly with friends as the night wears on? Yeah, you've been there. The later it gets, the more deeply foolish you become. What is that weird, late-night energy anyway?
